PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask the minister whether in his judgment it is right and proper that a decision on foreign ownership of a substantial proportion of the press in this country be dependent on a political leader's arbitrary interpretation of balanced reporting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The circumstances under which the decision was made to increase the shareholding in Fairfax in question have been fully explained in this place and elsewhere. It was not based on any question about the content of editorial comment or anything else. It was a decision based on the financial and economic management needs of the organisation which were perceived to be such as to justify an increase to protect the interests of the shareholder and, as a result, to protect the interests that everyone had in that investment in new technology being preserved.

PARA.TAB: The question of a balance, and the discussion associated with that, was wholly subsidiary and on the side in terms of its relevance to the circumstances of the particular matter. That was perfectly clear from the passages that I read into the record yesterday. I should also perhaps read into the record some relevant excerpts that I did not have with me yesterday but which are very clear in their content. They are excerpts from the interview with Mr Conrad Black on PM on Friday, 19 November. When asked to describe the nature of the deal in question, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: There wasn't a deal.
In the context of a similar discussion that he said he had had with Dr Hewson, Mr Black went on to say:

The only interest either man ever expressed was that the paper's quality be maintained and that professionalism be maintained, and where one or other of them perceived it had been lacking before, to be shored up. There was no discussion of deals and no discussion of partisanship.
In that same transcript, when the journalist asked a question about the inference being drawn by the opposition about these references to balance, Mr Black said:
Well, you can tell the Opposition that what Mr Keating said was virtually identical to what Dr Hewson said and they both behaved with the most complete probity.

There it is from the horse's mouth on this particular issue. There was obviously some discussion between Mr Black and Mr Keating on the virtues of balance and responsible media. There was equally obviously some discussion with Dr Hewson on exactly the same subject. There was no question of conditionality in either case and, accordingly, no basis for this line of questioning which the opposition continues futilely to pursue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister seems to have moved a long way away from what the Prime Minister said the other day which was, in fact, that permission to increase would be dependent on his assessment of balanced reporting of that particular media outlet. On the basis of what the Prime Minister said was important, I ask the minister: how does he interpret the meaning of balanced journalism?

—I am not going to get into that sort of area other than to say that, in the context of this particular exchange, the interpretation that was clearly adopted by Mr Black and what Mr Keating said was that the media in question simply be responsible. It does not mean that support can never be expressed for one side of politics or the other. In fact, clearly support was expressed for one side of politics in the last election—and it was not our side of politics, notwithstanding all the hares that those opposite are trying to set running in this particular respect.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter simply of an approach to journalism which is responsible, which has regard to facts, which does not mix comment and facts in a way that is manifestly unacceptable. Clearly, Mr Keating was expressing views of that kind. That is the view that Mr Black understood him to be expressing and, moreover, for present purposes it is not a view that was different in any significant way from the view that Dr Hewson was expressing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Could the minister inform the Senate of the implications for both superannuation schemes and their policyholders of the recent passage of the superannuation industry supervision bills? In particular, could the minister comment on what immediate steps should now be considered by fund managers to address the requirements of the legislation?

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for raising this issue and I thank the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I acknowledge very much the work that is being done by the committee. It has been diligent in its conduct of this matter, both under the chairmanship of Senator Sherry and, more recently, under the chairmanship of Senator Watson; I thank them both and the committee members from all sides of the chamber. I also acknowledge the efforts of my successor as parliamentary secretary, Gary Johns; they have allowed him to do some things that they would not allow me to do. They must think he is a lot better than I am—they might be right.
—I agree with you for once.
—Senator Crane does not have to be so enthusiastic in his agreement about that part.
—He couldn't be much worse.
—I thank Senator Ian Macdonald for his usual high level of contribution, but I thank his colleagues at least for their reaction to it.

PARA.TAB: It is an important package of legislation and it represents a major advance in the protection of superannuation savings. It has received a lot of support, not surprisingly, because of the comprehensive nature of the committee's review. It is designed to make trustees more accountable and responsive to their fund members, to enhance the scope for members to participate in the management of their funds and to ensure that the ISC has appropriate and effective enforcement powers.

The important part of Senator Chris Evans's question is: what transitional arrangements do fund managers need to consider between now and the impact of the legislation? The legislation will apply to those schemes from the commencement of the 1994 income year. So it will not be the same date for all but, of course, for most it will be 1 July 1994.

I want to make some points about what it is that those fund managers should be doing. During the period of up to seven months—maybe more for some, but certainly the seven months before July 1994—they really should be looking at getting their affairs in order in relation to this legislation. The government has now provided a very clear statement of the supervision and prudential requirements well in advance. A large number of funds will also need to initiate changes to their trust deeds and other supporting documentation to comply with the legislative provisions.

I urge those fund managers to consider these changes and not leave them until the last minute. They have been expressing concern that perhaps it was not clear what the government wanted from them. It now is, and I hope they will use this time to make those changes so that the trustees are more accountable, that the members have the greater role and that superannuation is used for genuine retirement purposes.

It is a very worthwhile package of measures. I think it will enhance the retirement income policy for all Australians. I thank once again the committee for its support; I thank Senator Chris Evans for raising this issue; and I urge fund managers to take the opportunity of this period before the legislation comes into effect to make sure their arrangements meet the proper requirements so that we can have a smooth transition to the new regime.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the minister of remarks made to a West Australian press gallery journalist by the Prime Minister when the journalist claimed that Mr Keating had been brought to heel by state premiers as a result of a special Loan Council and COAG meeting. Mr Keating is reported to have said to the reporter:

QUESTION.PARA: You are a disgrace. You, your newspaper and your editor are corrupt. You're finished and you'll never get anything else out of us.

That was reported on 13 December 1992. Does the minister agree that untempered remarks such as these indicate that the Prime Minister's sense of balanced journalism only exists when stories reflecting positively on him are written and that negative or less than flattering press is considered biased?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that follows at all. All of us on occasion can get a little testy with journalists when they behave in a fashion which lets their profession down, which demonstrates their lack of professionalism, particularly when they come from a newspaper like the West Australian, which is absolutely notorious for its inability to report, let alone report fairly and prominently, views that differ from its own. It is a difficult paper to live with at the best of times and it is not surprising that on occasion there would be some expression of concern of that kind expressed in appropriate terms by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Again, all this notion that this bears upon in some way the attitude that was taken by the Prime Minister and the government towards the shareholding issue in the present case is simply unfounded. In answer to a question of a similar kind from a journalist, Mr Black said:

ANSWER.PARA: You're being too suspicious, you see. You're imputing questionable motives to your Prime Minister. All he was seeking was professionalism, fairness and balance in the Fairfax titles and all I was pledging to do was my best to ensure that that occurred, but that contained no implications of partisanship in one direction or another, and indeed I had somewhat similar discussions with Dr Hewson.

So I think those opposite should get very clear in their own minds exactly what their own bloke was saying to Mr Black before they pursue these discussions any further. If he was saying no more than what Mr Keating was saying about the appropriateness of a sense of decency and professionalism in the way a paper is run, he was simply contributing to the public interest and not in any way undermining it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was very clear. It related to an abusive phone call that Mr Keating made to a West Australian journalist in which he said, `You, your newspaper and your editor are a disgrace'. That is what the question was and the answer should address that and not deal with the previous question.
—Order! I think the answer was relevant.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Considering that the minister has refused to answer the question that I actually asked, I will ask him again—
—It wasn't worth an answer. You do ask silly questions. You are a pathetic person.
—You, Senator Cook, are a silly little man. If that cap fits, it is okay by me.
—Order! Senator Knowles, ask the question. There are too many interjections from my right.

—Does the fact that Senator Gareth Evans does not like the newspaper, and the fact that the Prime Minister does not like what it prints, give a right to Senator Evans or anybody else to employ thuggery tactics of calling people totally corrupt—such as the newspaper, the journalist and the editor? Does it warrant that?

—I am not sure that I should respond to any question from someone who has been guilty of both sexism and sizeism in the way in which the question was expressed. It is a silly question coming from a senator who, on the face of it, ought to know better than to ask something quite as manifestly fatuous as what she put on offer on this occasion. She asked her question. I have given her a better answer than she deserves.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Does the Australian Bureau of Statistics study entitled Australian families, a publication released today, form part of the Australian government's commitment to the International Year of the Family? Does this survey debunk the myth of the decline of the Australian family? What does this survey tell us about the changing nature of Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I launched the results of a 1992 survey of the Australian family, done by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The publication released today, entitled Australian families, is one of a number of publications that will come from that very comprehensive survey.

PARA.TAB: The report presents very important findings about how Australian families are constituted and how their members care for each other. It gives us a good idea of who in Australia is living with whom and how they support and care for each other. We now have detailed information about ways in which family members support each other in areas such as employment, income, housing, child care, personal care, education and even transport. The survey should lay to rest the insidious message being promoted by some on the other side that people are turning away from their families, that people do not care for their families, and even that the family is collapsing.

What the survey clearly proves is that, although families in Australia are changing their shape and the way they are constituted, in the main they are going strong. This government recognises families in all their diversity, and so does this survey—it is just what the statistics show. To quote from one of the statements released today with the publication by the ABS, the results of the survey show:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . that family members draw on help from both their immediate and extended family in a variety of areas . . . such help is the central focus of an individual's support network.

Nine out of 10 people still live with at least one other family member. Of these people, the family unit of a married couple with dependent children is still the most common family type, at 43 per cent. One-parent families constitute up to 13 per cent. Of those one-parent families, 84 per cent are headed by a woman. Four per cent are step or blended families.

PARA.TAB: As this report shows, in the main the members of Australian families are very committed to each other. This report shows very clearly that, if things go wrong, the first port of call, the first person somebody turns to, is a family member. So I would like to ask why Dr Hewson allows John Bradford and 30 or 40 of his coalition cohorts who are members of the Lyons Forum to continue to bag the Australian family. Why does Dr Hewson's lot have the right to say that one sort of support of a loving family is better than another? I wish they would explain that. Indeed, I believe Dr Hewson should show a bit of leadership for a change and tell that forum to let Australian families get on with the business at hand—that is, caring and sharing with each other.

Indeed, the statistics do provide invaluable assistance to our understanding of the contemporary issues facing Australian families. These statistics of Australian families will very much debunk the myths circulating about families. They will be very useful in assisting government with policy making.

It is very important that we do not tailor government support for families to some myth about families as though they were constituted in the 1960s. We need to tailor policies to families based on the data we have about families in the 1990s. I think it is very important to note, too, that this survey was conducted last year as part of the government's contribution to IYF, the International Year of the Family.

More reports will arise from this material as it comes to hand, particularly focusing on families as providing carers and also on the important connection between workers with family responsibilities. Both of those are hinted at in this report. There is some evidence in the report, and further detailed information will be forthcoming with further surveys. I believe the ABS should be congratulated on its very useful data, which will assist government and, indeed, help debunk myths about the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister will be aware of remarks made by the Prime Minister at APEC about both the European Economic Community and the Prime Minister of Malaysia. Does the minister agree that APEC's existence means European nations should not be too smug or cocky—to use the Prime Minister's words—about their place in the world? Does he agree that the Malaysian Prime Minister has been recalcitrant over APEC? How do these comments assist Australia in the Prime Minister's own stated aims of urging European agreement on GATT and integrating Australian trade with Asia?

—I do not think a remark about the response of the European Community, or the European Union, to these trade issues of the kind that was made by the Prime Minister is going to even be noticed in Europe, let alone treated by the Europeans with the kind of response that would in some way undermine the likely endgame of the Uruguay Round.

PARA.TAB: The Europeans are used to very robust exchanges of this kind. Their own response to some of the key policy issues in the round has been less than forthcoming. They deserve to be stirred up on occasions. If the mere existence of APEC will have some incidental impact in making them rethink their role and status in the world and undermine some of the perhaps excessive confidence which existed in the past about their capacity to influence the rest of the world in ways to their own liking, but to nobody else's, so much the better. I do not think any question arises about those remarks.

As to the remarks made about Dr Mahathir, I believe that Dr Mahathir will very well understand the context in which those remarks were made. After all, Dr Mahathir has not himself shirked from making the occasional quite vigorous statement. Indeed, in the particular quotation put to Mr Keating which prompted his remarks there was one such rather vigorous statement. The truth of the matter is that, when provoked, as Mr Keating was on this occasion by a whole series of media inquiries, media interrogation, of the kind he faced in this instance, it is understandable that a remark of that kind might have been made.

It is disappointing that Dr Mahathir chose not to attend the APEC leaders conference, but he obviously had his own reasons for doing so and I do not think we ought to overplay the significance of either his attendance or his non-attendance on the one hand or of any remarks made by Mr Keating or anyone else about that.

Certainly, those remarks should not be allowed, as they have been rather by the Australian press, with its usual flair on these occasions, to undermine the significance of what has been a supremely important occasion so far as the history of this region is concerned and so far as the likely future of world trade is concerned.

The other point I would make, in fairness to Malaysia's role in APEC, is that we should never underestimate or undervalue the contribution Malaysia has in fact been making over the last four years to the success of the APEC process. It may be the case that it was not at this particular leaders meeting, but it has attended committees, working groups and all of the ministerial meetings, and it has made a splendidly constructive contribution all along the way in so doing.

So I think all of these things should be seen in their appropriate context and certainly I would not envisage any long-term consequences—in fact, with a bit of luck, any consequences at all—to flow from this particular, rather vigorous, exchange in a context that will be well understood on both sides.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Evans said that these people need to be stirred up from time to time. Does the minister think this is appropriate language for the Prime Minister to be using—`You abuse me and I'll abuse you back'? Does the minister not think the Prime Minister simply could have said to the Prime Minister of Malaysia that he missed something very important, that he missed a wonderful opportunity for Malaysia and that that is his loss? Why do we have to have this sort of language? Is it appropriate in international diplomacy?

—Senator Kernot will recall that I used the expression `stirred up' in the context of the first part of her question in relation to Europe, not in any other context. As to the other context in relation to the Malaysian Prime Minister, I have nothing to add to what I have already said.

Ray Braithwaite, M.H.R.
Federal Member for Dawson

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to an article in the Canberra Times of 21 April 1993, which referred to a phone conversation at the end of last year between Mr Conrad Black and the Prime Minister in which the Prime Minister is said to have warned Mr Black, `If you touch me, I will knock your'—expletive deleted—`block off'. With this statement in mind, can the minister confirm to the Senate that this is the commonly used means by which Mr Keating seeks to achieve what he calls balanced reporting? If so, how can the Prime Minister maintain that he should be the sole arbitrator of what is considered balanced reporting in the context of Mr Black's application to increase his holding in Fairfax?

—I am certainly not familiar with the article in question. I am not familiar with the conversation, if indeed any took place. I am not prepared to accept Senator Minchin's version of that or any other conversation of which I do not have direct evidence. As to its implications for the present circumstances, I have explained all those fully in answer to previous questions.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Against the background of the reported statements by the Prime Minister and his recent statements on this issue, why is it not reasonable for the Australian people to believe that Mr Keating made it perfectly clear to Mr Conrad Black that he could only increase his holding in Fairfax if his papers were sympathetic to Labor?

—It would be wrong for any such inference to be made because it runs directly counter to every public statement that Mr Black has made about this issue, quite apart from the responses that Mr Keating has given. Unless Senator Minchin in this place, under the cover of privilege, seeks completely to impugn Mr Black's integrity as well as that of the Prime Minister, it is quite inappropriate to accept the claims that are being made. Senator Minchin is making a series of scurrilous imputations about a course of events which has been fully and accurately described in the terms that I have amply put out on the public record in answer to his questions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to previous announcements that the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research was to undertake the first ever long term survey of immigration to Australia. Can the minister inform the Senate of the progress of that survey? Further, is he aware of any media interest or involvement in the project?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for a question which relates to what is probably the most ambitious and far-reaching project ever undertaken by the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research. The longitudinal survey to which Senator McKiernan refers should be under way by February next year and will run until around the turn of the century. The results from it will be used for planning and service delivery for many years into the future.

PARA.TAB: The basis for the survey will be conducted by Reark Research. It has been commissioned to survey about 5,000 principal applicants for permanent residency, applicants who will arrive in Australia over the next six years. They will be interviewed three times within six months of their arrival, again a year later, and a third time two years after the second interview.

I am pleased to say that, as the survey progresses, there will be another project running in tandem with it and parallel to it. That project is expected to make the migrant experience accessible to the whole Australian community, from the migrants' first impressions as new arrivals to their lives as settled residents.

SBS television has been interested by the survey. Its Dateline program has expressed an interest in a joint project with the bureau, to run parallel with it. Details of an agreement between SBS and the bureau are being finalised. However, the proposal is for SBS and its program to follow a small group of migrants and monitor their progress from before their departure from their homeland to their long-term settlement within Australia. The migrants featuring in the documentary will be part of the longitudinal survey, but of course they will be identified and concessions will be made for their participation in the program.

The survey of immigrants to Australia will be enormously beneficial to Australian policy makers and to community groups. The survey itself will build on the prototype survey which was conducted in 1991-92, which has provided valuable information to a wide range of researchers and agencies in a wide range of government departments. The other important aspect is that not only will it be a source of essential and extremely comprehensive data and information, but the access that the Australian public will have to the migration experience through the SBS documentaries should greatly increase the general understanding of what is involved in settling in a new country.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the minister seen the report released last week by Amnesty International which suggested that Australia is implicated in human rights abuses being committed on Bougainville? How is Australia reviewing its relationship with Papua New Guinea in light of this report? Will the minister recommend to the Department of Defence that it use the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade human rights manual in its training program? Will the Australian government make further representations to the Papua New Guinea government urging access to Bougainville for humanitarian agencies?

—I am aware of the report, although I have not yet had the opportunity to study it in detail. The Australian government shares Amnesty's concern at reports of continuing human rights violations on Bougainville, both on the part of PNG security forces and the Bougainville rebels. That said, it has to be acknowledged that the situation there is a very complex one and it is very difficult to obtain unbiased accounts of incidents involving claims of human rights abuse. For that reason the government welcomes the statement that was made on the weekend by defence minister Tohian that the PNG government will fully address the Amnesty report and its recommendations.

PARA.TAB: I reject the inference that the Amnesty allegations have damaged Australian government credibility on human rights in the region. Our commitment to upholding human rights is absolutely universal in its application. We have regularly raised our concerns about possible human rights abuses on Bougainville with the PNG government, emphasising the need for appropriate disciplinary or legal action to be taken against offenders from whatever side, and specifically urging the government to seek a political solution rather than a military one to the conflict on Bougainville.

Our policy in the human rights field is well known internationally. It has been well stated recently by the Prime Minister. We simply will not compromise on questions of democracy, our commitment to human rights or in our respect for human values.

As to the question about reviewing our relationship with Papua New Guinea, we have long recognised that, to be influential in achieving human rights objectives, we need to be aware of the totality of issues which make up any particular bilateral relationship. In this regard—as I and the Prime Minister have said on other occasions—we seek to handle human rights issues consistently but sensitively, only in very exceptional circumstances doing anything other than relying on quiet persuasion. Punitive or other sanctions can be relevant on occasions, but we do not see them as being relevant here.

The suggestion contained in the Amnesty report that we consider suspending military aid to Papua New Guinea in the circumstances of the Bougainville situation is simply not a constructive one. Australian defence assistance to PNG is aimed at developing that country's defence force capabilities across the range of its constitutionally defined functions, which include national security protection, fisheries surveillance, search and rescue, support for internal security and aid to the civil power. Our defence assistance also extends to supervision of civil engineering tasks in two provinces and communications assistance to PNG police. It perhaps ought to be stated again, because it seems to be constantly misunderstood, that we are providing no direct operational assistance to PNG security forces on Bougainville.

Senator Bourne's question on the human rights manual was an interesting one; I am sure Defence will be interested in it. I will certainly see whether Senator Ray and his colleagues in Defence are interested in using it; I think they might derive some benefit from it. I am indebted to Senator Bourne for her suggestion.

In relation to further representations about humanitarian agencies' access to Bougainville, the government, both publicly and privately, has been urging the PNG government to give humanitarian agencies access to Bougainville. Indeed, it was as a result of an initiative taken by us in 1990 that the first international NGOs were allowed access to Bougainville the following year. All of these issues will be raised during the forthcoming Australia-Papua New Guinea ministerial forum, which is being held in Mount Hagen in about nine or 10 days time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to two consultancies totalling over $403,000 to pay for the services to AQIS of Mr Peter Bisset, who held the position of business services manager from September 1991 until this month. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I refer to media reports of a 50-year-old woman, recently widowed after 33 years of marriage, who nursed her mother, father-in-law and husband through their terminal illnesses and has four children and 11 grandchildren, and who has now been forced out into the long job queues without any choice in the matter. Why was the decision to abolish the widow's B pension not phased in? What consideration was given to continuing the widow's pension for such widows in the likely event of their long absence from the paid work force? What cost-benefit analysis has been done of the returns from retraining 50-year-old widows for employment, as opposed to training unemployed younger people, taking into account the different expected length of work force participation? How many widows who would formerly have qualified for a widow's pension are represented in the unemployment figure? Finally, will the government recognise the rights of these widows and give consideration to restoring the widow's B pension to them so that they can have a choice of widow status or labour market traineeships?

—The widow's B pension is being phased out over a period of 15 years which began in July 1987, so there is a phasing out period. Since July 1987, no new grants have been made to widows aged under 45 who receive the sole parent's pension and some others under 50 years of age. So the widow's B pension will cease to be paid early next century when all women who have qualified since 1987 attain age pension age and residency.

PARA.TAB: As part of the simplification of the superannuation package, the Treasurer announced new arrangements regarding the preservation age. From 1 July 1992, the preservation age became 55 for people born before July 1960, 56 for people born from 1960 to June 1961, 57 for people born between 1961 and 1962, 58 for the next year, et cetera, so that for those born after June 1964 the preservation age is 60. New arrangements replaced the standard preservation age of 55 years.

Appropriate consideration was given to preserving the widow's B pension for younger women but it was decided that younger women whose work force opportunities were not restricted by caring responsibilities should be expected and encouraged to re-enter the labour force rather than become dependent on the welfare system. The phasing out of the widow's B pension from 1987 was well publicised and families were permitted to make any preparations they decided were necessary. It is not the role of government to promote the life insurance industry.

A cost benefit analysis of the sort proposed has not been undertaken. The Department of Social Security is intending to evaluate the changes to the widow's B pension as part of its portfolio evaluation plan strategy in 1996. Re-training for those suffering particular work force disadvantage—such as women who have been out of the work force for long periods—remains, of course, a government priority. It is not clear what costs and benefits this question refers to. It should be noted that the government does provide considerable assistance to people providing care for sick or elderly relatives through carer's pensions in the social security system and tax rebates in the taxation system.

That is the official answer and I will editorialise briefly at the end of it. Regarding this particular case, because women are so young at 50 it is logical that that age bracket was the one most targeted to do away with the widow's B pension. Not all women who reach the age of 50 are going to be in a situation of having 33 years of marriage, four children and 11 grandchildren. As a result of Senator Harradine's question I will approach the Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, to see whether we can get any flexibility in the rules. I do not believe it is a good idea to simply encourage all those who are widowed to go onto social security. Encouragement to go into the work force and the provision of training courses are welcomed by many and I think that should be encouraged, but this case does show up to me, at least, the need for some flexibility and I am going to ask Mr Baldwin whether that can be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the government undertaken or will the government undertake an assessment of the risk to northern Australia of fallout from a major nuclear accident in Java? What is the government's current assessment of the safety risk to the Australian public arising out of the Indonesian nuclear power program? Given the proposed nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement between Australia and Indonesia does not rule out Australia's involvement in the development of Indonesia's nuclear power program, what plans does the government have to fully inform Australia's citizens of the implications of that proposed agreement before it is signed?

—I can take those questions in reverse order. The Senate will be aware from a number of previous statements I have made that information about that agreement has been on the public record since 1991. Discussions on its conclusion are still taking place with Indonesia. There is no hidden agenda about that. The object of the draft agreement is to enhance Australia's existing and mutually beneficial nuclear science and technology cooperation with Indonesia in areas such as nuclear medicine, radiation protection, nuclear related safety information and applications of isotopes. As Senator Margetts should be aware, that agreement will be made public on signature in the course of normal procedures and subsequently tabled in parliament.

PARA.TAB: As to the risk question, as I have said before—and it is true that I have been asked questions about this before—I do not see that the alleged risks from a well-regulated nuclear power program using the latest western technology, as planned by Indonesia apparently, will be severe or as substantial as claimed. The Indonesian government has not yet made a decision on the type of reactor to be chosen for its program. The reactor designs it is considering, however, are all western water cooled reactors incorporating the latest technology and advanced safety systems.

I should also like to point out that it is completely misleading to draw erroneous comparisons with Chernobyl. Any reference to a potential Chernobyl-type accident is valid only for nuclear power plants with that particular Soviet type reactor, known as an RBMK type reactor—a design built only in the former USSR, which in 1989 decided in any event not to construct any more reactors of this type. Indonesia is not contemplating using a Soviet designed or built power reactor to meet its energy needs.

Following the Chernobyl disaster, quite extensive examinations of its causes and consequences carried out by the International Atomic Energy Agency and the relevant committees of the Nuclear Energy Agency of the OECD found that the basic failure was due to the RBMK reactor which, due to a fundamental weakness in its design, could be very unstable under certain operating conditions. According to the 1993 report of the UN scientific committee on the effects of atomic radiation, Chernobyl is the only accident that has occurred in a civilian nuclear powered installation that has resulted in radiation doses to members of the public greater than those resulting from exposure in one year due to natural sources.

The only other major nuclear power reactor accident which has occurred during the accumulated 6,500 years of commercial nuclear power reactor operation—namely, that at Three Mile Island—had completely different radiological consequences to Chernobyl. That reactor, like all western reactors and unlike that at Chernobyl, was housed in a containment building. The Three Mile Island accident released a large portion of the core inventory of fission products. But most of those fission products were retained within the containment system and, as a result, the accident had minimal public health consequences.

I will finally say this: Indonesia's first power reactors are not due to come into operation until 2003 at the earliest. Needless to say, the Australian government will be engaging in close dialogue with the Indonesian authorities, which have been quite open about their nuclear power program as their plans evolve, making clear any concerns that we may have as that program does evolve. We will certainly be maintaining our very close interest in the development of that Indonesian nuclear power program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Considering the geographical nature of Indonesia's location in an earthquake zone, does the minister never intend to establish an inquiry to investigate the risks associated with Indonesia's nuclear power program?

—I have addressed the question before about the impact of the particular geology of Indonesia on the power reactors concerned. I have made the point that, on all available evidence, modern engineering techniques are amply equipped to cope with any stresses associated with building in zones of that kind, as indeed has been demonstrated in Japan, which is located in a classic earthquake zone. I do not see the occasion being likely to arise for an inquiry of the kind that Senator Margetts has spoken about. Of course, we will continue to closely observe developments in this matter. Our overriding concern will always be for the safety of the Australian people. At this stage, for all the reasons that I have spelt out, there is no reason to believe that any such inquiry would be remotely necessary or would be likely to achieve any useful purpose.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to Senator McDonald's question:

The IWTO funding offer was first made at the IWTO conference at Istanbul in May 1993. Senator McDonald rightly recognises that it has been Minister Crean who has actively sought to engage the IWTO and to bring their offer to fruition whilst others have simply chosen to write the offer off as a myth and not even try.

While there is a continuing preparedness on the part of many processors to make a contribution to wool promotion, the difficulty is to find an acceptable mechanism to collect the funds and meet their concern that their competitors are also paying. On this basis the IWTO has asserted that the only effective way to do so is to impose a levy at the point of export.

I point out that there were nearly 3,000 applications for grants in the last round, which indicates the strong support the community has for this program.

I think this is extremely embarrassing for the opposition senators. The opposition tried a political stunt yesterday. Mr Truss obviously did not check with his Liberal and National party colleagues what they thought of the Brothers rugby club in Mackay. Otherwise, they would have warned him not to bag the club and not to accuse it of doing the right thing by Labor, because they had all written in support of the club.

Senator O'Chee said, `It is a wonderful sporting facility for the people of Mackay'. Those opposite were all saying, `This is the sort of thing we ought to do in regional towns around Australia'. Senator O'Chee said, `How wonderful my constituents of Queensland are, and I am representing them'. No wonder those opposite are embarrassed. No wonder they are trying to draw attention to the political point in the speech made by Mr Truss yesterday which accuses this rugby club of Mackay of being a political front for the Labor Party.

It has been exposed today that those opposite were also supporting this grant. They are now crying and whingeing that something terrible has happened. The only thing terrible that has happened is that the truth has got out. Despite all their whingeing and whining that this program is a political stunt, opposition senators were trying to support it and get a grant of $150,000. But they did not tell Mr Truss what they were doing, so he spilt the milk. In other words, it is all over those opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion. Not only is the coalition suggesting that this grant was a political stunt; the Auditor-General's report states exactly the same thing. In answer to a question yesterday, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) said that the department went through the applicants and worked out who was and was not eligible. If an applicant was not eligible, the application was not considered.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's report states that the review showed that nine per cent of the projects approved by the minister were from category 1; 80 per cent were from category 2; and 11 per cent were from category 3. In other words, proportionately more category 3 projects were approved, which the department defines as:

SPEECH.PARA: ". . . lacking in relevant information for which community need has not been adequately demonstrated and many other selection criteria not satisfied, including evidence of other funding sources. . . "

More of those projects were approved than category 1 projects, which clearly demonstrated community need and satisfied all selection criteria. The category 3 projects also received a higher proportion of the available funds.

PARA.TAB: What other motives could there be for including these category 3 projects other than a political bias? I am sure that the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Schacht, is well aware of what happened in South Australia prior to the last election. In the marginal seat of Grey, which the Labor Party had held since World War II—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, since 1969.
—Labor did not have it for a short period of three years. Other than that, it has held it since World War II.
—You won it only because of the boundary changes.
—We won it because people understood exactly what Labor was trying to do to that electorate. Apart from the fact that there was a better campaign—
—And a better candidate.
—There was a better candidate. The marginal Labor seat of Grey had 22 separate allocations totalling $434,000.
—Is Barry Wakelin complaining?

—Barry Wakelin is not complaining. Labor's barefaced political stunt has been seen for what it is. Twenty-three separate grants totalling $434,000 were made to Grey while a total of $291,000 was granted to Port Augusta, Port Pirie and Whyalla.

PARA.TAB: Minister Kelly says that these grants are made on a needs basis. The fourth lowest income area of Australia, as set out by the Industry Commission, is the Eyre Peninsula. In that part of the electorate of Grey, $143,000 was granted compared to $291,000 to the cities in the area. I ask the Senate to compare that to the Liberal-held electorate of Wakefield, which got four grants totalling $92,000, or the electorate of Barker, which got five grants totalling $116,000. I remind honourable senators that Wakefield contains the lowest income area in the whole of Australia.

We have heard from the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) that many people are presently competing for the lowest income title under this government. Certainly Wakefield contains the lowest income area in the whole of Australia, which is the Yorke Peninsula-Lower North region. In 1991 it had an average annual personal income of $13,224. The other three lowest income areas were the statistical divisions of Murray Lands, which is in the electorates of Wakefield and Barker; Eyre, which is in the electorate of Grey; and the Wide Bay-Burnett area in Queensland.

The joke is really on the government in this particular case because having spent $291,000 on the cities of Port Pirie, Port Augusta and Whyalla and a total of $434,000 in the electorate of Grey, Minister Kelly found that the political stunt and the political bias did not work because the Liberal candidate, Barry Wakelin, was elected. He is the first Liberal member elected to that seat since Liberal's former Senator Donald Jessop held the seat for three years after World War II.

Grey got more than the average because it is a very marginal seat, but three-quarters of the money went to the cities, and the people in the rural part of Grey, in the low income area, got a very small proportion of the money. Wakefield and Barker got hardly any money at all, despite both having areas with the dubious distinction of being amongst the bottom income areas of Australia. The grants made by Minister Kelly were not based on real need. They were based on the need to buy votes in marginal Labor seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the debate on this motion to take note of Senator Schacht's answer. I also welcome—but with some concern—the fact that some senators on the opposition benches addressed the needs of their electorates and took an interest in this particular program. This program has done a lot of good right across Australia in electorates that are held by Liberal members, in electorates that are held by National Party members, and also in electorates that are held by Labor Party members. One thing that has not been mentioned in this debate is the fact that there are far more Labor members of parliament than there are National members of parliament in the House of Representatives. There are also far more Labor members of parliament than there are Liberal members of parliament. So when we look at the figures, we come to some semblance of understanding of what is going on with this particular grant.

PARA.TAB: In commending the senators who wrote letters and who were named here this afternoon for doing their job and representing their electorates—and senators represent the whole of their state—I draw attention to the fact that not all members of the House of Representatives, particularly opposition members of the House of Representatives, made representations on these particular grants. They did not support the wishes of their electorates, including clubs, in making applications for their grants. That has to be taken into account when looking at possible discrepancies which may or may not have been pointed out by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch).

If Senator Ian Macdonald, Senator O'Chee and Senator MacGibbon are having any influence on decision makers in these matters, that does cause me some concern, but I have noticed the balance in that former Senator Lady Flo Bjelke-Petersen was also giving support. That is probably why this particular club was successful on this occasion.

I will address the matter of whether or not marginal seats got the money. The most marginal Labor seat in Western Australia—indeed, in Australia—was the seat of Stirling, held by Mr Ron Edwards. The safest opposition seat in Western Australia—I believe it is very close to being the safest seat in Australia—is the seat of O'Connor. Which got the most money? Senator Panizza is a great rural representative in Western Australia. I ask him: which got the most money? Which electorate in Western Australia, if we are looking at the allocations by electorate, got the least amount of money through this series of grants? Let me surprise the Senate. Let me surprise, particularly, Senator Panizza who is left speechless by the question I inadvertently addressed to him. It was the seat of Stirling which got the least amount of money. The safest opposition seat of O'Connor, with nearly 70 per cent of the vote, got far in excess of what was allocated within the region of Stirling.

It does not stop there. Another marginal seat very close to my heart because my electorate office is situated within it is Cowan, which was formerly held by that magnificent member of parliament, Mrs Carolyn Jakobsen. Unfortunately, she is not with us now. I hope that in the short time she will be away from the place, she will take elocution lessons and then come back and represent her constituents using a better form of English than she used in the past, but that is a hope for the future.

The electorate of O'Connor, the safest coalition electorate in Western Australia, got more money through this grants system than the electorate of Cowan. Even if we add the figures for Cowan and Stirling together we will find that O'Connor got more money. That knocks the proffered argument that the money was being allocated wholly and solely to Labor marginal electorates. It shoots it out to baloney.

I know that Senator Ferguson will claim that there are shades of grey in this argument. I do not accept that. There are statistics, damned lies and statistics. I suggest that in this debate about allocations and grants a lot more damned lies have been used than proper analysis of the statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Senator McKiernan made his contribution, I am even more concerned about these grants. Senator McKiernan is suggesting to the Senate that because Liberal Party politicians support a grant it should not be made. That adds more concern to this whole scheme.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Schacht that I am in no way embarrassed by supporting this proposal. I thank Senator Schacht and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in the other place for raising it and letting the people of North Queensland know that Senator MacGibbon, Senator O'Chee, Mr Braithwaite and I support our electorates.

I am very proud to have been able to assist the rugby league club in Mackay in getting grants that were available. Mackay is a community which I know well. In my earlier days, I often played sport in that town because I was a representative basketballer. I was very pleased to be able to support this application by the Mackay Rugby League Club.

These rorts perpetrated by the Labor Party in spending taxpayers' money as if it were its own simply to buy votes is not confined to the sports area. I mentioned yesterday and I mention it again now that in the local capital works program the same sort of figures and calculations exist—66 per cent of the funds go to Labor electorates and 33 per cent of the funds go to Liberal electorates. On average that is about $6 million per Labor electorate and $3 million per Liberal electorate. That adds fuel to the argument.

I will write to the Auditor-General and ask him to look at the local capital works project as well as these sports grants because it seems to me that there is too much of this going on. The Labor Party, Senator Schacht—as a former functionary, flunkey and apparatchik for the Labor Party in South Australia—and even Senator Ray are past masters at using taxpayers' money to buy votes for the Labor Party at difficult elections.

It is a disgrace and it should not be allowed to happen. The people of Australia should be made to realise that these grants are not playthings for the Labor Party to buy votes. For Senator McKiernan to suggest that he is amazed and concerned that the grant was given to Liberal and National Party electorates whose politicians supported the project is outrageous. I would not have thought it possible that Senator McKiernan would make that sort of suggestion. It has shocked me deeply to find that members of the Labor Party are suggesting that this goes on.

I hope that the Auditor-General can take the sports matter further. I hope that he will look at the matter in relation to the local capital works program because the sooner we blow out of the water this disgraceful, undemocratic way of the Labor Party using taxpayers' funds to buy votes in marginal seats the better; it has to stop.

TALK.START.PARA: —This political debate we are having on Senator Reid's motion to take note of the answer that Senator Schacht gave really is a little like looking into an infinity of mirrors. All the coalition seems to want to do since 13 March and since the parliament resumed is look back. It wants to look back in very great anger at the reasons 1993 passed it by, as indeed the 1990, 1987 and five elections in total passed it by. That is not really a substitute for crafting an alternative political position in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator MacGibbon has made a couple of contributions that really ought to be the subject of response. I remember a conversation I had with Kim Beazley years ago when he was Minister for Defence. He said that the worst approach that an Australian government could take to defence planning would be to solve the problems of the 2nd AIF in 1939-1945 and be prepared to fight the previous war again. Essentially, that is what the coalition is continuing to do—to fight the previous general election all over again without recognising that, unfortunately from its perspective, the election has been comprehensively lost.

As a direct consequence of this kind of looking back down the infinity of mirrors, by 1996 the coalition will have achieved a perfect blueprint for winning in 1993. Senator Minchin understands that better than most. Senator MacGibbon said that it was an absolute tragedy that the Labor government of Bob Hawke and Paul Keating rested on preferences from time to time. Yet that ignores Australian history. One does not have to be a psephologist or Malcolm Mackerras to look at Australian history from 1949 right through to 1972 at either a national or state level. As Senator Kemp knows very well, the Bolte Liberal government in Victoria rested more often than not on DLP preferences, just as federal—

TALK.START.PARA: —Too much on 40 per cent.

—Precisely—Senator Ray is absolutely right. It never went anywhere near a majority of votes. I do not even have to discuss the state of Queensland. Under the Nationals, majority votes were not even considered—one did not even have to worry about that during the period of National Party government. The simple fact is that we have a preferential voting system. When it comes into play, if one's party is skilled enough to put together a marginal seat strategy—which Senator MacGibbon dismisses with disdain; I am really pleased that he does—one will achieve enough preferences to win individual electorates and, overall, one will achieve government.

PARA.TAB: By 1996—the current defence Minister might be interested in this—the coalition will have achieved a perfect strategy for winning the previous general election. But the problem in the interim is that the country is the poorer because the opposition is so devoid of ideas. An absolute poverty of spirit is evident opposite. So the longer the coalition looks back in anger, the longer the Labor government will stay in power—until 1996 and well beyond. I make these remarks on the basis that when we look back in five years time, I believe my observations will be borne out by the facts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1993

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement clarifying a matter which arose in a debate last night.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I refer to the debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 which took place last night. Mr President, you will remember that after 10.30 p.m. there was debate on an Australian Democrats' amendment, which sought to insert a preamble in the principal act. We opposed that insertion but did not divide because of the time. Therefore, our opposition was not recorded. There has been some query this morning as to whether we supported or opposed that insertion. I wanted to put on the record, as I have just done, that in fact we opposed it; we called `no'.

PARA.TAB: We did so primarily because, of course, it is a nonsense to seek retrospectively to put in a preamble to an act that has been in force for some years. That is apart from the fact that we were not shown the normal courtesy by the Australian Democrats of being given the amendment in time to put before our party room, as is the usual procedure. I wanted to put that on the record so that there is no uncertainty about our position. We opposed the insertion of that preamble.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Last evening, as were approaching the last half hour of sitting, I asked the Senate attendant for the Democrats' latest amendments to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3). I was given a document described as No. 1, which is dated 22 November 1993. I have it here if anyone wants to see it. That was the only one I was handed.

PARA.TAB: I immediately asked for the preamble. I was informed it was no longer relevant, so I screwed it up and got rid of it. I was not given a new one. That preamble was dated 18 November 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were given the wrong advice.

—Yes, I was. Later, when I was talking to Senator Troeth about what we were going to do, lo and behold, even though I was told that the preamble was irrelevant and I was not given one to take its place, Senator Kernot moved the amendment inserting the preamble, spoke very briefly and sat down. I got back to my seat and looked for the—
—Stunt politics.
—Yes. I got back to my seat and attempted to find the screwed up preamble. I could not find it.
—We have accepted your apology; sit down!

—I am not apologising. I have a few questions to ask. Senator Collins then spoke, and that was it. I ask whether this amendment was distributed. To my knowledge it was not. Can any honourable senator tell me differently? As I understand it, the amendment was written by the government. When I eventually got hold of it this morning, it was not marked as a revised version.

PARA.TAB: I claim that we were misled last evening. Coalition members definitely called `no' but the Hansard does not show that. It just shows Senator Collins advising government support for the amendment. The amendment was then agreed to and the remainder of the bill, as amended, was agreed to. It does not show that we all called `no'.

I want it put on the record that we all called `no' and opposed the amendment. At another time in the appropriate forum I will go through that preamble. We are very disappointed that we were misled and not shown the amendment, which I was told was no longer relevant.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The attitude of the government on this matter is that Senator Hill has placed on the record that, in fact, the opposition opposed the amendment. That is appropriate. If any senator thinks he or she has been grossly misled or that there have been inefficiencies in circulation, it is always the attitude of the government that these matters can be recommitted. We always follow the principle that the will of the Senate, as reflected by the votes, must be followed and that inadvertence, whether it is caused by poor circulation or anything else, should not be allowed.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Hill has probably put on the record where the opposition stands on the issue, and that corrects it. If these events occur in future, the government will always take that stand and the matter will be recommitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of eight day care centres draws to the attention of the Senate that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Childcare Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne (from 64 citizens), Senator Coulter (from 199 citizens) and Senator Harradine (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detained;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:

PETITION.PARA: to end the policy of detaining asylum seekers, and
to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Exports to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1.Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2.We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3.This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sandy Macdonald (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)is of the view that the forthcoming general election in the Republic of South Africa should be both free and fair, and should reflect popular electoral opinion accurately;

(b)draws to the attention of the Government of South Africa the simple fact that it is the Government's responsibility, and that of all its agencies, specifically that of its security forces, to ensure that the poll is free to the maximum extent possible from attempts to intimidate voters or to direct such violence against the election process that the ballot is rendered null and void;

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains on Managed Investments

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on some of the 23 treaties which the government tabled in the Senate this afternoon. I have no doubt that many of those treaties are most worthy documents and will be of assistance to this country. Of course, one cannot tell because the government has not given any sort of explanatory note in regard to some of these quite complex treaties to enable us to determine their purpose and what their impact will be.

PARA.TAB: This raises a fundamental issue. In many areas, particularly in relation to the United Nations, this government is treaty mad. As a consequence, merely by the stroke of the executive pen, a whole host of new obligations have been entered into without any consideration by this parliament or, indeed, any of the state parliaments which may well be affected.

Australia is comparatively unusual in this sense. We do not have a proper process to look at and review treaties, and to ensure that parliament has a chance to examine the nature of the treaties which are entered into. I think this makes us quite different from most other comparative countries. For example, in the US these treaties would have to be approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate.

This issue has been raised before in the chamber. I think it is important that the Senate give closer consideration to what should be done to make sure that the treaty arrangements governments enter into are properly examined by this parliament. I now have 3 1/2 minutes in which to complete a brief comment on these 23 treaties, which, of course, is impossible.

As I said, the treaties can come into effect by the mere stroke of the executive pen. Within these 23 treaties—I have had a quick look through them—there are some treaties of considerable importance. I notice that treaty No. 9 on this list is the treaty that we signed with the government of Nauru—the settlement of the International Court of Justice case. This case has cost the Australian taxpayers $107 million. The government has persistently refused to table the legal reasons why it decided to settle this case.

I have in my hand the submission that the government made initially to the International Court of Justice which explained very carefully why we should not settle this case and why Australia did not have an obligation to pay $107 million. Since that earlier submission to the International Court of Justice, the government has changed its mind. Mr Keating went to an international gathering in Nauru. On the day he arrived he announced that the taxpayers would be paying compensation to Nauru of $107 million. As yet, I do not have any bit of evidence except the assurances by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) that there was a legal justification for carrying this out.

This list also contains what looks to me to be a very important treaty. The so-called Vienna agreement is a very important document which will govern how particular treaties are interpreted in the international arena. As I have said, there is no covering note to explain to the Senate and interested senators the importance of this treaty. Nonetheless, I am sure, because it will govern the interpretation of many treaties that Australia has entered into, that it is a document of quite some significance.

The final documents on the list relate to two UN committees to which Australians now have right of appeal. Again, they are short treaties and deal with the remuneration of members of those committees. I have long opposed the government's policy of overturning the philosophy of the Australia Act and allowing domestic disputes in this country to be examined by UN committees. These UN committees are not properly structured to carry out this work. I believe that this is quite contrary to the wishes of the Australian people and contrary to the philosophy of the Australia Act. (Time expired)
