TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities entitled Differential voting shares and the Australian Stock Exchange.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments will be brief because I spoke on this matter during last Thursday's matter of public interest discussion. This report arises from a discussion paper put out by the Australian Stock Exchange. In turn, the discussion paper is a response to a proposal by Rupert Murdoch of Newscorp for the Australian Stock Exchange to waive its listing rule 3K to allow News Corporation to issue super voting shares.

PARA.TAB: While the committee has not been able to see the Murdoch proposal, I understand that it was made clear that Newscorp wanted the decision made by January. According to newspaper reports and gossip around the business world, it is believed that it also signalled that if it is not successful then it will move its listing offshore. It is not an insignificant threat. Brokers' commissions from the trading of Newscorp over the last year, for example, may be as high as $60 million. Of course, the brokers are the same people who make the decisions at the Australian Stock Exchange.

A number of serious questions are raised by the paper, and these are listed in the report. There is the possibility of the entrenchment of control by current major shareholders; the possibility of one group of shareholders in a company being able to increase its proportion of voting control without formal takeover or acquisition of equity; the possibility that such acquisition of control may be in breach of the takeover code as set out in chapter 6 of the corporations law; and the possibility that ordinary shareholders will lose rights and that, as a result, the value of their shareholding might diminish.

It is generally accepted in the industry that wherever the proposed changes have been introduced they have had the effect of keeping the present management in power—in this case, keeping the family in control. Page 4 of a publication called Corporate Governance Bulletin, dated July-August 1992, released by the Investor Responsibility Research Centre in the United States, where this debate has been going on for some 10 years, states:

These recapitalizations often are used by family-controlled firms to ensure that family hegemony is preserved, even if the company issues large amounts of additional common stock, resulting in a dilution of the holdings of non-family stockholders.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee has been unable to give full consideration to the substantive question—that is, the merit of introducing super shares—simply because there has not been time to do it. However, the committee did want to comment on the process of making the decision, and the report focuses on five areas that go to this process.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the committee was particularly interested in the time allowed for responses to the discussion paper put out by the Australian Stock Exchange on the Wednesday before last. Responses are expected by 29 November, and a decision was expected to be made in the middle of December in readiness for a decision to be made by News Corporation shareholders in the middle of January.

This debate is new to Australia, but it has been a long and bitter debate overseas, particularly in the United States and Canada. At page 4 of its report, the IRRC refers to the debate as one of the most incendiary corporate governance debates of the 1980s. And it is still unresolved. Yet the Australian Stock Exchange seemed keen to push the decision through in a time frame not designed to suit Australian shareholders, and not designed to suit the Australian business community, but designed to suit News Corporation Ltd. We do not think that is good enough. We think that the time ought to be extended for that reason. Recommendation (i) of the committee's report says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the ASX allow until the end of February 1994 for submission of views and comment on the complex issues raised in its discussion paper `Differential Voting Rights'.

That is a reasonable extension of time. It is not taking it out too far, but it is giving some time for the many interested groups in the community, many of whom have contacted us, formally and informally, to respond to what is a very complex issue.

PARA.TAB: The second thing that the committee was interested in was that the principle of one share, one vote is a fundamental principle and that any change to that principle needs very serious consideration. In fact overseas trends, if anything, seem to be in the opposite direction to that proposed by the ASX. The trend overseas—in continental Europe, England, Canada and the United States—seems to be back towards re-enfranchising voters and moving back to the principle of one share, one vote.

The third thing that the committee was particularly concerned about was the impact on the Australian Stock Exchange and whether the Australian Stock Exchange had the capacity to make the detached and objective assessment that needs to be made in this very difficult area.

I have already talked about the influence that a company the size of News Corporation can bring to bear on the Australian Stock Exchange—by dint of its brokerage fees, if nothing else. We are wondering whether the headlong rush to make a decision here is not precipitate and unnecessary, and whether that demonstrates that the Australian Stock Exchange does not have the true independence to be able to make a detached and objective assessment. We are concerned also about the impact that this might have on the Australian Stock Exchange and its reputation overseas. We believe that it might well undermine its integrity. The very speed with which it is dealing with this issue might be seen to be answering the call of one big listed company. We believe that this might undermine the ASX's credibility and integrity.

Another matter that the committee was concerned about was the need for the Attorney-General, the Australian Securities Commission and government to be fully involved both in responding to the Australian Stock Exchange's discussion paper and in looking at the longer term issue of who should be making decisions on really fundamental issues like this—whether it is good enough to leave it to, effectively, a self-regulatory regime governed by the ASX or whether the government should not be involved at a much earlier stage.

We are concerned, for example, that if a waiver is suggested by the ASX, the government has no control over what might happen. If a listing rule change is suggested, then section 774 of the corporations law does allow the Attorney-General 28 days to disallow that change to the listing rules. A waiver does not give him that same power, although we do note that in a letter to the committee, which is included in the report, the ASX has committed itself to a course of action which would involve both the corporations and securities committee and the Attorney-General should a waiver be decided. Recommendations (iii) and (iv) go to that involvement of the ASC and the Attorney-General. Recommendation No. 3 says:

SPEECH.PARA: That both the ASC and the Attorney-General prepare a response to the ASX discussion paper `Differential Voting Rights' and publish those responses.
Recommendation No. 4 says:

That the Attorney-General examine the longer term implications of decisions on such fundamental issues as differential voting rights for shares being made by bodies which may be subject to undue pressure and/or face possible conflicts of interest.

PARA.TAB: The fifth thing the committee was interested in was that if any change were to be made, it should be by a change to the listing rules for the reasons that I have already indicated. If something is good in principle, then the rules ought to be changed for everybody and the proper process given the right to go through. If a listing change is made, for example, the Attorney-General has 28 days to disallow it. He has some time in which to examine that listing change and he has the capacity to disallow it in consultation with the ASC and, presumably, the Attorney-General's Department.
The committee does not support the idea of waiver—the approach of case-by-case exemptions—as a good way of applying their rules. Recommendation (ii) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that any change in ASX requirements which would permit alteration to the current one-share-one-vote rule should be implemented by means of amendment to the ASX listing rules. The Committee strongly opposes the introduction of such changes by waiver on a case-by-case basis.

The report is a simple but important response dealing with process because we simply do not have time to deal with the substance or merit of the case, but we think it is most important to let the Australian Stock Exchange and the business community know that the process is not acceptable to the committee and that we will be following this debate very closely.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that yesterday, somewhat astonishingly, the Senate refused to refer to its own estimates committee the question of financial concerns that arose out of the allocation by Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, of the sporting, recreational and community grants. The Senate is also well aware of the Auditor-General's report which raised these very serious worries that, in fact, moneys may have been allocated other than in an objective way and that they may have been allocated on a determination based on political bias. This is a very serious matter and one would have thought that the Senate would have leapt at the opportunity to analyse this issue and resolve some of the supplementary issues that were left outstanding by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: One issue was, of course, that the Auditor-General was unable to get from the minister the documentary evidence that was necessary to make a determination as to the basis upon which she chose one grant applicant over another. The Auditor-General was referred back to the department and the department simply did not have the necessary documents. Therefore, it is only the parliament that has the capacity to get to the bottom of this matter and it is the Senate, with its proud record of doing its best to ensure proper financial accountability of the government, to which the Australian people look. In this instance, however, the Australian Democrats and the Greens refused to support the Senate in its quest to simply recall the appropriate estimates committee in order that it might examine this matter. It is not a major request of the committee; it is quite a simple, standard, ordinary, everyday occurrence.

What had occurred in this instance was that the Auditor-General's report had been put down a few days after notice would have had to have been given for the supplementary hearings of that estimates committee and, therefore, the relevant questions were not raised. Now that the Auditor-General has put that report down, the very serious concerns are on the public record. A sensible course of action would have been for the Senate to recall the estimates committee and have the matter looked at. It could have been done in the course of one day's debate. The Senate would have had the opportunity to question the minister, the minister's representative in this place and the department to find out exactly where the truth was in this very dubious circumstance.

Regrettably, however, the Australian Democrats and the Greens decided that, because the matter was before a House of Representatives committee, there was no necessity for this chamber to meet its responsibility. A House of Representatives committee, I remind the Senate, acts in accordance with the numbers in the House of Representatives. It simply does not have an independent authority. It gets instructions from the majority and it acts in accordance with the determination of that majority. That is why the accountability function of this chamber, apart from the expertise that it has built up over a long period of time, can be more appropriately brought to bear to find the truth.

The government does not have the numbers in this chamber. One would have thought that the majority, made up of the coalition, the Greens and the Democrats, would have got on with the job that this Senate exists for, which is to ensure the financial propriety of the government. But the Democrats and the Greens abdicated that responsibility. They determined that this parliament would not meet that responsibility and that the committee would not be allowed to function in the way in which it has been structured to achieve the objects for which it has been structured.

Yesterday's decision was astonishing. But nevertheless, that was yesterday's debate. It was a sad day when the Democrats and the Greens were not prepared to stand up and say, `We demand that this government account, and that the investigation of the Auditor-General be pursued by this chamber in order to answer the so far unanswered questions'. Anyway, that was yesterday.

Today, I am seeking an order of the Senate that the documents that Minister Kelly and the department have that are relevant to this matter be tabled in the Senate by tomorrow. They are all obviously available because they have been searched in the last few days, as evidenced in an answer from Senator Schacht today. We are requesting that they be tabled in the Senate tomorrow so that honourable senators and the Australian public can make a determination through another means about where the truth is to be found in Minister Kelly's very doubtful exercise of her role.

It is not a major exercise that is being sought of the Senate; it is a pretty simple task. The documents are at hand. They can simply be tabled in accordance with an order of the Senate. Therefore, it is another challenge today for the Australian Democrats and the Greens to determine whether they are really interested in the financial accountability of this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1993 and indicate that the coalition will be supporting this bill. It seeks to increase the appropriation for the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program. It is through this program that Aboriginal education is funded and evaluated as part of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy which commenced in 1990.

PARA.TAB: The particular measures in this bill seek to increase funding for the years 1993 to 1995. It will seek to increase the appropriations for this program by approximately $2 million over a 2 1/2-year period. The extra money will contribute to some very important educational programs which are specifically targeted to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

This funding for education is particularly important as was stated by the Aboriginal education policy task force in 1988. The government's Aboriginal education policy is largely based on the report of the education policy task force. In the report the task force said that it was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . deeply concerned that in spite of several improvements in educational opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people over the last two decades, the disadvantage faced by Aboriginal people in securing their right to education remains far more severe than for any other group in Australian society.

These findings of five years ago are just as relevant today. Aboriginal education has certainly improved over the last few years with slight increases in participation in higher education and a better improvement in school retention rates.

PARA.TAB: Participation in higher education by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people rose from 0.5 per cent in 1987 to 0.9 per cent in 1992. The year 8 to year 12 retention rate in Australia has risen from 17 per cent in 1986 to over 30 per cent in 1990. Additionally, the proportion of Aboriginals who have not attended school fell from 33 per cent to eight per cent.

Although these improvements are very good, they do not really go far enough. We need parity between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians in both participation and outcome. Until we have this, we need to ensure that the funding for these programs is properly targeted. An important start is the fact that the goals and educational principles of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy is endorsed by all governments in Australia. This is essential if we are to have a coherent and coordinated approach to national Aboriginal education policy.

The coalition supports the major long-term aims of this policy, which are to increase ATSIC involvement in educational decision making, to ensure equality of access to educational services, to achieve equity in Aboriginal participation and to enable equitable and appropriate educational outcomes. The policy also allows for the Commonwealth to fulfil a strategic planning and monitoring role while the states concentrate on implementation. This is sensible, as is the high degree of Aboriginal involvement in the decision making process in implementing and developing the policy. The coalition supports all of these things but the question remains: are we achieving enough? This is what all Australians must ask.

The Aboriginal education strategic initiative program, which provides funding specifically to supplement educational funding arrangements, is the program affected by this legislation. A multitude of reports and article on Aboriginal education, including the Hughes report, have identified various common factors contributing to the continuing low level of education in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. These include: lack of access—for example, living in remote out-stations; lack of cultural suitability of the education; language difficulties; lack of understanding and appreciation of cultural differences in non-Aboriginal communities, often resulting in the marginalisation of Aboriginal children in the school system and consequent lack of self-esteem; poverty, leading to poor health; and unfavourable conditions of home study.

The Aboriginal education policy has set three main objectives for the second triennium of 1993-95. These are: firstly, the implementation of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which specifically relate to education; and, secondly, the implementation of the national Aboriginal languages and literacy and strategy, which aims to improve the English literacy of Aboriginal primary and secondary students, particularly those for whom English is not a third language. It also focuses upon the teaching of Aboriginal languages in schools and supports regional language centres and community projects. The third objective is the implementation of the national reconciliation and schooling strategy, which aims to promote the reconciliation process through the schools system.

Unfortunately, while these admirable objectives should be fulfilled, the policy has set reasonably vague priorities for the next three years. It would be preferable if the government set specific targets at which to aim. We should be specifically aiming for higher retention rates and participation rates.

The Hughes report actually recommends setting benchmarks, suggesting that state and territory governments be encouraged to recognise the extent of non-participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in education. It suggested adopting targets for increasing participation of Aboriginal children in primary and secondary schooling from 85 per cent to near 100 per cent and lifting retention rates of Aboriginal students from year 8 through to year 12 from a rate of 17 per cent to at least 65 per cent by the year 2000. Why is the government so reluctant to set such benchmarks? The policy of the government should be more firm about what it is attempting to achieve and the coalition believes we need more measurable outcomes.

A further criticism of the current policy is that it lacks flexibility. The coalition believes that Aboriginal education, as with all education, should be based on choice. Over the past few years there have been various points of view surrounding the question of systems of independent education for the Aboriginal community. There have been instances where Aboriginal people themselves have set up independent schools. Some of these have been successful and some have not. This is a reflection, of course, of what happens in the broader community.

Excellent examples of such schools exist. Some of these in New South Wales are very successful, where parents have had the choice of sending their children to mixed stream classes or to Aboriginal children only classes. Although this was initially criticised as a separatist approach, it went ahead with parental approval. The results have been that Aboriginal children are now making much better educational progress. One notable success is that of the St Ignatius Catholic School in Bourke. St Ignatius reports:

SPEECH.PARA: Attendance figures have soared, staff turnover has dropped and the marks of Aboriginal children now range across the board in school tests.

These positive outcomes have given credit to the idea—and this is the kind of flexibility that is needed in our educational system—that if Aboriginal children are to get the most benefit from the money which goes towards them in education we need the flexibility of approach that we have seen at schools such as St Ignatius.

PARA.TAB: In the broader Australian community, if we could have separate schools for girls, different schools for religious affiliations and remedial classes for children with learning difficulties, our education system should be flexible enough to accommodate Aboriginal only classes if the results show marked improvements in education. It is particularly important, however, that such plans are carried out with the complete understanding and approval of parents and that they always constitute positive action, as opposed to separatism. There are many who might think that this positive action constitutes separatism or even apartheid. However, there is a very clear distinction, for apartheid acts to restrict options. Enforced separatism assigns control to the dominant power and limits choice, with the aim of containment. Positive discrimination, on the other hand, relies on a good measure of support from the community and it aims to assist this, as is the formula used by St Ignatius where the emphasis is on parental consultation and continuing choice.

Given the diversity in our educational system already, the funding under this program should take into account the different needs of Aboriginal children throughout Australia. Education is one of the greatest needs of our Aboriginal children. It has been shown that the attrition rate for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students at university was around 40 per cent. Part of the reason for this was the cultural differences and the different values for Aboriginal students as opposed to mainstream students in areas relating to academic success.

Aboriginal students place more emphasis on values associated with tradition, conformity, security and power. Mainstream students place emphasis upon values associated with achievement, self-direction and stimulation. Aboriginal students hold values serving collective interests, as opposed to mainstream students, who hold values of individual interests. This distinction is very important in education.

If fundamental cultural differences shape value systems, which in turn influence a student's entire educational experience, these differences need to be the basis of our different approaches to education for these children. It is very important to take these cultural differences into consideration when developing the most appropriate educational policies for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That is why flexibility is very important in Aboriginal education policy, while at the same time providing solid educational foundations to ensure better employment and participation in Australian society for these children. An important balance is needed in Aboriginal education.
Finally, in the words of the Hughes report, which has so strongly informed current policy:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . equality for Aborigines in education is essential to the economic, social and cultural development of Aboriginal communities. Perhaps the most challenging issue of all is to ensure education is available to all Aboriginal people in a manner that reinforces rather than suppresses the identity of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
The coalition supports this view and, as a result, supports this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Democrats are quite ready to accept and endorse much of the content and sentiment expressed by Senator Tierney, we will present an individual reaction to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill. The bill allocates funds for the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program and continues the Commonwealth government's national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy.

PARA.TAB: In 1989 the government introduced the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy and identified long-term goals. Those goals have been identified by Senator Tierney. They include: the involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in educational decision making; equality of access to educational services; equity of educational participation and appropriate educational outcomes. An evaluation of the AEP scheme was announced this year to determine the effectiveness of the policy.

An examination of the rates and types of participation by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in education reveals some significant statistics. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in all forms of education is the lowest experienced by any group in Australia. Aboriginal enrolments have increased in higher education. Between 1982 and 1992 enrolments rose from 0.3 per cent of total enrolments to one per cent, which translates into 854 students increasing to 5,105 students. Clearly, there is still room for a great deal of improvement there.

Although the completion rates for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students have almost doubled in the four years from 1988 to 1991, this is not reflected in the total number of higher education completions, which have also increased from 0.4 per cent to 0.6 per cent. Some of the specific problems associated with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students include a high level of attrition, on average a longer course completion time for degrees and a lack of particular services for Aboriginal students on campus.

It is appropriate that the government eventually withdrew the punitive and unfair budget proposal for a minimum time rule in higher education. It was proposed that students who failed to complete their degree in the minimum time would have incurred a 50 per cent increase in their HECS debt for each additional unit of time that was taken. It is important to acknowledge that it was as a result of combined Democrat, student and, eventually, opposition pressure that the government did excise this clause from the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill. All of those who added to that pressure on the government are to be congratulated, as is the government itself to be congratulated for finally seeing the light. It was that particular proposal which was estimated to have a particular effect on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, who are likely to take longer than the minimum time to complete their tertiary courses.

The government has developed education strategies to increase Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in higher education. As part of its equity strategy the Commonwealth meets with institutions to determine their profiles but, despite incentives for institutions in the form of funding to increase the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, most institutions fall short of their goals.

The government contradicts its own rhetoric about access and equity by imposing financial disincentives to entering and participating in higher education on all traditionally disadvantaged groups. It seems quite duplicitous for the government to purport to a commitment to access and equity when it imposes barriers to increased educational opportunities for groups such as women, mature age students, those from low income backgrounds, people who are disabled and people who come from indigenous backgrounds.

This duplicity is illustrated by the fact that, on the one hand, the government is encouraging further participation but, on the other hand, budgetary measures, or so-called budgetary measures, are having the effect of positively discouraging that very participation. To illustrate that, we have only to look at the regressive changes to education in this year's budget, such as double HECS payments for second degrees, increased repayment rates and levels for HECS itself and an increase in student loans. They are all financial disincentives and they are all financial barriers for all students, but they are especially effective in placing a barrier in front of those from lower socioeconomic groups, in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are disproportionately represented.

The Australian Democrats oppose these budget changes, in particular the decision to double HECS for second degrees. Again, this is a measure that will discourage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders from undertaking second degrees. The Democrats will vote against these HECS measures and, if the government and the opposition are sincere in their rhetoric about access and equity in higher education, they will oppose the changes also. I must say that we often hear the phrase `access and equity'. It is glib, it is easy to say, but it is not true that the more you say it, the greater the access and the equity. There has to be consideration of the effects of the actual measures that are being implemented.

In the area of student financial assistance, the Commonwealth provides Abstudy, which assists some 40,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students. Unlike the other parties, the Australian Democrats are committed to providing adequate levels of student financial assistance for students. The government offers below poverty line income support with restricted eligibility criteria and penalties for students who wish to earn additional money through employment.

We support the key features of the government's Aboriginal educational policy for the second triennium because it includes the implementation of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, the national Aboriginal languages and literacy strategy and the national reconciliation and schooling strategy. But we insist that the relevant recommendations of the royal commission be implemented as soon as possible. We are glad to see the increased employment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education workers and the expansion of preschool services that will begin from 1994.

The Aboriginal literacy strategy which commenced this year is an important strategy that will provide indigenous people with the opportunity to improve their English if it is not their first language. This is an important measure at a time when as many as 10 to 20 per cent of the Australian adult population is considered functionally illiterate. That is according to Words at work, a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into literacy needs in the workplace.

The role of Aboriginal studies in the process of reconciliation cannot be underestimated. It is a significant step towards enriching our whole culture as well as providing indigenous people with a chance to see their history, achievements and culture reflected in and not written out of our history. We must recognise the important role of education in self-determination.

Small inroads have been made during the past 20 years in the area of improved education for indigenous people. Retention rates in secondary schools and participation in higher education have increased but, as I stressed earlier, there is still a long way to go. As Senator Tierney rightly said, it is the measurement of such outcomes which determines the success of the theories. It is appropriate to keep monitoring those particular outcomes as an objective test of the rhetoric.

The government has an obligation to provide all Australians with an accessible and equitable—those words again—education system. Yet this is one area in which the opposition and the government are failing Australians as they further entrench this fallacy of user-pays education. Many of the government's initiatives contained in the Aboriginal education policy are commendable, but I urge the government to reconsider its overall attitude towards education which sees students paying more in individual contributions, particularly those from traditionally disadvantaged backgrounds.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders make up one of these disadvantaged groupings. They have the lowest level of representation in the education sector. Government platitudes are not enough. A genuine commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders involves removing obstacles, some of which I outlined just now. These are the obstacles that prevent and discourage people of all sizes, shapes and descriptions, but they have a particular effect on those who are disadvantaged. These people are discouraged. It is that very discordance between the policy of glibly saying, `We are encouraging a certain group of people', or `We are making particular policy efforts to encourage another group of people', and then delivering up a budgetary measure which has the opposite effect. The opposite effect is the one which has to be worn, particularly by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students.

DEBATE.TITLE: FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH LEVY BILL 1993FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1993FOREST INDUSTRIES RESEARCH IMPORT CHARGE BILL 1993

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The federal coalition welcomes the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill 1993 and cognate bills. The bills before us provide for the establishment and funding of a Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation which the forestry industry has sought for some time. To finance the corporation and its activities, there will be a levy on wood produced in and exported from Australia as unprocessed wood, and on unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products imported into Australia.

PARA.TAB: While Commonwealth and state governments already contribute to research through their various departments and the CSIRO, the Australian Forestry Industry Council, consisting of the relevant state and federal ministers, believes more can be done. All major reports on the forest industry—including the Resource Assessment Commission's 1992 forest and timber inquiry, the National Plantations Advisory Committee and the ESD working group on forest use—have echoed the urgent need for a better coordinated and better focused research program. All believe that more research is essential if Australia is to increase productivity and value adding in the forests and wood product industries, and to manage our forests in an ecologically sustainable way.

The new Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation will identify national research priorities and assess research gaps. Moreover, it will commission, administer and evaluate research into a broad range of areas relating to wood production, extraction, processing, economics and marketing. The corporation's charter will include the ecological and environmental impacts of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations. However, it will not undertake its own research but will call for tenders from those organisations which can and do undertake the type of research required.

As with other rural research and development corporations, it will have a high degree of industry involvement and accountability. The industry, through the National Association of Forest Industries, or NAFI, will be closely involved in the selection of a board of directors for the corporation. At this stage, I seek leave to table the annual report for 1992-93 of the National Association of Forest Industries.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important statement because it brings together in an annual report a review of the operations of NAFI in 1992-93 as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: .liaison with politicians and their advisers
.liaison with various government departments on matters affecting the industries
.development of ties with other associations
.gathering and disseminating information on commercial, environmental and political issues relating to the forest industries
.ongoing development of a national market development program
.speeches to industry gatherings
.assistance and support to community groups through the Forest Protection Society Limited
.management of industry liaison with schools and educators
.liaison with associated groups both within the forestry industries and the wider economy
.liaison with media and preparation of articles for journals, newspapers etc.
.tours of the forest industries
As I said, this is a very important report and I certainly draw the attention of honourable senators and other persons to it.

PARA.TAB: The corporation to be formed must prepare a five-year plan in consultation with the industry as well as annual operating plans for each financial year, which are consistent with its five-year plan. Annual reports will be tabled in parliament and available to the industry.

I now turn to finance for the corporation. The amount of levy to be paid by industry will be set by regulation. However, it will not exceed the legislated maximum rate of 0.5 per cent of the average value of production of that class of wood and, from what I understand, it is likely to be well below that maximum. The Forest Industries Research Levy Bill 1993 relates to the levy on unprocessed wood delivered to a mill and this levy will take effect on 1 January 1994.

Four different levy rates will apply to different classes of wood: hardwood sawlogs, softwood sawlogs, hardwood pulp logs and softwood pulp logs. The levy is not only payable on domestic wood but, through the Forest Industries Research Import Charge Bill 1993, is also payable on imported unprocessed wood. A separate account will ensure that money collected from imports is spent on research and development relevant to the timber importing industry.

The Forest Industries Research Export Charge Bill 1993 collects the levy on unprocessed wood that is exported instead of being delivered to a mill. The Commonwealth will provide $1 for every $2 collected from the domestic industry to a maximum of 0.25 per cent of the gross value of production of the industry. The reason why the Commonwealth contribution is $1 to $2 and not dollar for dollar, as with other primary industries, is that only half the industry has a primary industry focus—that is, tree production and small rural sawmills as opposed to the other half of the industry which is based on manufacturing. The Commonwealth will not match import levy funds.

It is expected that annual contributions from the domestic industry will be around $700,000. The effectiveness of the corporation will be reviewed in 1995-96. It is important to note that the timber industry has enormous potential for growth and that, until now, it has largely concentrated on the domestic market which supplies some two-thirds of Australia's needs. Yet Australia imports more than $2.4 billion worth of timber product, much of it high value pulp and paper products, and exports only $775 million worth of product, leaving a deficit of $1.6 billion.
My colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) believes that there is no guarantee that this situation will change. He recently told the House of Representatives:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, I believe that it could get worse. All the best research arrangements in the world, or in Australia, will not do anything to overcome that very bad trade deficit unless there is security for investment to expand the utilisation of our forests—whether native or plantation.

With resource security, the forest industry can and will expand. As a prominent value adding industry, it will be able to create thousands of jobs and reduce not just Australia's trade deficit in timber products but help boost exports. The ACTU estimates that nearly $7 billion worth of job creating investment in this country is being tied up by what is euphemistically known as `green tape'. Much of that is in the development of products from forests and plantations which are, unquestionably, a renewable and sustainable resource.

PARA.TAB: It is a pity that the government seems little short of paralysed when it comes to making decisions about the future of the forest industries. We have seen arguments between ministers about whether exports of woodchips will be phased out altogether after the year 2000; we have seen a failure to obtain resource security for the 1,200 timber mills scattered across Australia; and we have seen a minister in charge of forests have the ground cut out from under him. We can only conclude that the government never wanted resource security legislation but rather the image of friendliness to the timber industry and forest industries.

By contrast, the federal coalition's policy was, and is, to legislate for resource security without any reference to the size of the project. We believe that the sawmill that wants to spend money on a veneer plant, a drying process or anything that adds value to timber has just as much right to be guaranteed supply as does a pulp mill.

There have been about 18 reports by committees of inquiry into the forest industry, and it is difficult to think of any that the industry lost or that found against the industry and its continued expansion. The so-called mother of all inquiries was undertaken by the Resource Assessment Commission. It took years to complete, used almost an entire forest to produce its report and was favourable to the forest industry. The industry might then have expected to be allowed to get on with the job. But no, the government responded with yet another inquiry; this time it was by the Industry Commission and it also turned out to be favourable. So will the industry now get the legislation which the Industry Commission says is necessary, the Resource Assessment Commission says is required, the opposition has proposed and which is unquestionably vital to the future of the industry?

The coalition recognises that the most efficient, cost-effective and environmentally sound method of forest management is an integrated harvest system. If a tree is to be cut down for sawlogs, it is important to use it all. Apart from pulp mills and the few places in Australia which value-add by turning the chips into board, which can then be veneered or turned into furniture, the rest is exported or far too often burnt on the forest floor. Unfortunately, there are still people who believe that the industry logs native forests just for woodchips. In fact, it is difficult to get rid of chippable material at the moment. The lack of market for forest thinnings and sawlog residue is costing jobs and making sawlogs, and therefore timber, dearer.

It is also important to recognise the difficulty of persuading people to invest in plantations in Australia, mainly because of the long delay between planting and harvesting. We need to encourage more people to invest in farming trees and developing plantations, and address the current inequity and disincentive in the taxation system. As my colleague the member for Gippsland pointed out in the House of Representatives:

The creation of a forestry research and development corporation is long overdue and greatly needed. I know all too well that the industry has suffered a long investment drought. It is necessary only to have looked at the CSIRO's old Division of Forest Products as it struggled to obtain industry funding for its important research programs to have recognised the scale of this problem. In some regions throughout Australia little more than a tractor has been provided over the past decade, let alone a heavily industry funded research program.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, I trust that you will perhaps at some later stage reiterate your brother's concern in that regard.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Yes, senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you share his interest. Having said that, I commend the industry on its progress so far and urge the federal government to create the right environment for this industry to realise its potential. The development of a rural research arrangement for the forestry industry has long been supported by the federal coalition and, as a result, we welcome and support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three cognate bills, the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill, the Forest Industries Research Export Charge Bill and the Forest Industries Research Import Charge Bill. It is debating this package of bills to establish and fund the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. The establishment of the corporation was first announced in the national forests policy statement released last year by the then Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, the package comprises three bills. The first bill imposes a levy on unprocessed wood produced in Australia and delivered to a mill somewhere in Australia, and the levy is payable by the operator of the mill. The second imposes a charge on the export of logs produced in Australia and exported as unprocessed wood, and the charge is payable by the exporter. The third imposes a charge on the importation of unprocessed wood and certain classes of primary processed forest products, and the charge is payable by the importer. These charges will allow the corporation to come into operation on 1 January 1994. The corporation will be established under the auspices of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act.

Let me say at the outset that the Australian Democrats will be withholding support for these bills. We will be doing that until the government gets serious about implementing the national forests policy statement in toto. We are basically in agreement with the purpose of these bills, but we are not prepared to see the government pick and choose parts of the national forests policy statement—which has been assented to by the Commonwealth and all states, with the exception of Tasmania—and simply implement those bits it wants to implement and leave behind those bits that it finds unpalatable or those bits it simply does not have the political will or stomach to see implemented—because we are quite convinced that the government does, indeed, have the power to implement those other bits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it have the support of the states?

—I thank Senator Watson for that interjection. The situation is that the states have assented to this policy, but the states themselves are going against the policy. In those circumstances I think it is—
—It is a deceptive policy.

—Deliberately deceptive of the federal government to have gone into an intergovernmental agreement knowing full well that it was then going to use that intergovernmental agreement as a document behind which it could hide rather than implementing the policy as agreed. So the Democrats are prepared to support these bills as long as the government enforces the strategy to protect old-growth forest and wilderness areas; in other words, we are prepared to support the policy in toto, not in bits and pieces. Why should we allow the government to implement the industry-friendly aspects of the national forest policy statement while it sits on its hands in relation to the environmentally-friendly aspects of the same statement?

PARA.TAB: The fact is that these bills make it perfectly obvious where the government's priorities lie. Unfortunately, the government's priority is to develop at all costs and be damned with the environmental consequences. Here we have a package of bills which give effect to the commitment on research and development in the national forest policy whilst the commitment on forest conservation in the same policy is being violated. It is being violated even as we speak in this chamber tonight, and it has been violated around the country in every single state, including Tasmania, which, as I said earlier, did not assent to the national forest policy. Nonetheless, the federal government still has the power—corporations powers, trade and commerce powers, external affairs powers, heritage powers and so on—to make the policy bite in Tasmania even though that state had not assented to it.

A few weeks ago the Senate debated an urgency motion put forward by Senator Chamarette on the need for the government to implement its own forest conservation policy. Clearly, the government is failing to do so. The substance of my question yesterday to Senator Cook indicated quite clearly that the government is prepared to sit on its hands until 1995 or 1998 with respect to public and private lands in which, in time, most of the old-growth forests will have been seriously damaged, if not removed altogether.

But, as I said in my speech to Senator Chamarette's motion some weeks ago, not only is the federal government failing to act in this important respect but it even propounds the view that there is nothing it can do to save the forests. As I have indicated, this is blatantly wrong; it is not true. The federal government has a number of constitutional powers which it can use to stop logging in old-growth forests. The simple fact is that it lacks the political will to take tough action to save our forest heritage.

I understand that the office of the Minister for Resources propounds the view that the so-called moratorium clause in the national forest policy statement does not actually mean what it says. I will quote that section to honourable senators so that we are in no doubt what the national forest policy says, and what the states, with the exception of Tasmania, and the Commonwealth have actually assented to. The policy says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . until assessments—
of forest conservation values, including old-growth values—
are completed forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

Any person who understands the English language should be able to understand what those words mean. They clearly mean that there will be a moratorium in relation to those areas of forest having high conservation values until those assessments are complete. That is absolutely incontrovertible from those words.

PARA.TAB: However, apparently the minister does not believe that clear-felling old-growth forests which have recognised and established high conservation value will significantly affect the forests. I ask the minister, as I asked the minister yesterday and he did not reply, the following question: if clear-felling does not significantly affect the forest, what the devil does significantly affect the forest? One cannot do more damage to a forest than clear-fell it. One certainly cannot retain all those qualities contained in an old-growth forest—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no such thing as clear-felling now.

—Senator Watson has just interjected that there is no such thing as clear-felling now. I will take Senator Watson to some areas of forests where I and members of my staff have been in recent days and he will see clear-felling over large areas. I assure him that not a tree is left standing in those areas.

PARA.TAB: Clear-felling of old-growth forests is not a sustainable activity, by definition: it destroys wilderness. If one cuts down trees that are 300, 400 or 500 years old, it will take 300, 400 or 500 years more to get that wilderness back again. One cannot go on doing that sort of thing and retain the values which are inherent in the notion of ecologically sustainable development. Such a notion requires, among other things, the preservation of equity between generations, the maintenance of options for future generations similar to the options which are available to the present generation. The destruction of wilderness is then clearly a violation of that principle of equity between the generations. It irreversibly closes off options for future generations, and this government is supposed—and I use the word with some cynicism—to be committed to the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

The old-growth forests are now being destroyed and will be replaced by regrowth of new forests. The old-growth forest, with its majestic beauty and richness in species diversity, will then be gone forever. Clearly, if one understands anything at all about ecological relationships, one would realise that the spurious claim made by many people who would destroy the forests that the animals that live in hollows and so on in one area of the forest will simply take up hollows in surrounding areas of forests simply indicates a total lack of understanding of ecology. In natural ecological systems most of the niches are already filled and one cannot destroy part of that forest and expect the animals to leave that area and find places in untouched areas of other forests. The areas in the surrounding forests have already been occupied.

This government has a policy to stop this environmental crime, which is an injustice to this generation and all future generations. It must implement the requirements of the national forest policy and protect the forests. These forests are not ours to destroy; they are ours to look after. We have inherited them from our parents and grandparents. Therefore, are we going to simply sit back and allow them to be lost? How will our children and grandchildren judge us? I believe that they will judge us very harshly indeed.

What makes the situation even more disturbing is that the logging of our native forests is a loss-making exercise. This is the second point that I want to stress. We do not even make a profit out of this environmental destruction. We actually pay people to come into our forests and destroy them and, in the case of the export of timber and chips, we pay foreign companies to come in and take our forests away.

In May of this year the Victorian Auditor-General's office released a special report on Victoria's timber industry strategy. The report stated that in 1990-91, in the case of hardwood operations, a loss of $13.2 million was recorded. The report said that the department was unable to refute claims made by conservation groups that the industry is heavily subsidised by the Victorian public; in other words, the Victorian public are paying those companies to cut down trees to destroy their wilderness and forests.

The Resource Assessment Commission forest and timber inquiry report stated that in 1989 Victoria's forest service made a loss of $39.9 million. It also stated that Victoria's cumulative net loss from 1927 to 1989 was a massive $1.086 billion. When one recognises that the value of money in 1927 was a tiny fraction of what money is today—this is not presented in 1993 dollars—that $1.086 billion is an absolutely massive subsidy which has gone into forestry in Victoria. The Resource Assessment Commission figures corroborate the figures in the Victoria Auditor-General's report. Therefore, one does not have to take one report at face value because numerous reports substantiate this claim.

Victoria is not alone. The Resource Assessment Commission report stated that the cumulative loss from 1927 to 1989 of other state forest agencies were as follows: Queensland, $1.536 billion; New South Wales, $1.033 billion; Tasmania, $520 million—a tiny state with a small population subsidising its forest industry to the tune of $520 million to have its forests destroyed; Western Australia, $443 million. (Quorum formed) I am quite disgusted at Senator Vanstone's effort to waste time. She obviously does not like hearing what I have to say.

The losses which have been incurred by state forestry departments and commissions around Australia have been well and truly corroborated. In 1990 the New South Wales public accounts committee released a report on the New South Wales Forestry Commission, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The entire timber industry in New South Wales revolves around a system of substantial public subsidies.
That comes from a coalition government, not a Labor government. The committee reported that in 1989-90 the commission subsidised the forestry industry to the tune of $16.2 million.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, the economics of the native forest hardwood industry do not stack up. The industry survives on government subsidisation. No other industry in Australia is subjected to the same degree of protection or privilege. I am surprised that the opposition continues to support forestry in the way it does, given as it is to cutting out government subsidies left, right and centre.

The debt is created by the willingness of state governments to underprice eucalypt logs and to bear the full cost of road construction and maintenance and many of the other infrastructure costs associated with forestry. It is illuminating to note that in only one state, South Australia, does forestry make a profit. For many years, forestry in South Australia has been based on plantation timbers. I think there is a clear message in that for forestry in every other state.

I now turn to the minister's second reading speech. I was very concerned to read that the National Association of Forest Industries is to be closely involved in the selection of a board of directors for the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. The National Association of Forest Industries is not known for its sympathetic attitude to forest conservation. Although consultation with NAFI would not be improper, involvement indicates a much cosier relationship with government. If NAFI is to be closely involved, I hope that the minister will involve other key interest groups, such as conservation groups, which have tremendous experience and expertise in forest issues. I am sure that they would also appreciate being closely involved—to use the minister's term—in the selection of the corporation's board.

There are also those who have already substantially added value to Australian timbers. In taking evidence in relation to these bills in both Western Australia and Tasmania, one hears repeatedly that in clear-felled areas those who are value adding most—and there are a number down in the south-west forests of Western Australia and in Tasmania—have been excluded from going into those clear-felling areas and taking out the smaller, high quality trees for making very high quality and high priced furniture. For many years, those craftspeople have been excluded from going into those areas and taking those high quality trees which are not suitable for sawlogs in the normal sense of that use.

As most honourable senators would be aware, a report leaked earlier this year in WA revealed that the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management has been actively and systematically censoring the findings of its own research scientists. That is another point that I want to stress. The department had at the time been advocating that the wood yield from native forests in WA

SPEECH.PARA: would be doubled without any adverse environmental effects. The leaked report revealed that the department's own scientists had presented evidence which showed that the department's current level of logging was unsustainable.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this year, Professor Ian Lowe of Griffith University said that the senior managers in CALM had perverted the scientific process by suppressing results that threatened the interests of commercial parties—all adding up to the dangers of putting people from NAFI in such a powerful position.

In closing, I would like to also mention that our forestry activities are currently being carried on with enormous wastage. One need only go into any clear-felled area to see the amount of timber which is left on the forest floor. It is estimated that some 30 per cent of the timber is simply wasted.

The other evening, after I made a speech on forestry, Senator McGauran got up and pointed out that I had not said very much about unemployment; that I had spoken a lot about the environment. Having looked at the Hansard record, I find that in the last 6 1/2 years I have made 38 references to unemployment, whereas Senator McGauran, in his 3 1/2 years in this place, has made only seven references to unemployment. So, far from being concerned about the environment to the exclusion of things such as unemployment, my record is incomparably better than Senator McGauran's on this matter. Clearly in relation to unemployment it is the high capital, high cost industry and woodchipping which are leading to the loss of employment in the forests, not the conservation movement, which is seeking the protection of more and more areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be able to deal with what Senator Coulter has contributed in his speech because the short time I have been given, which was agreed to by my whip, allows me only a few minutes. I did not really want to talk about the nub of the issue—that is, the establishment of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. I am sure that will be dealt with across the chamber by people such as Senator Gibson, Senator O'Chee and other colleagues of mine, who will be able to refute some of what Senator Coulter has said. I look forward to hearing the contribution by my Greens (WA) colleagues, Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts, on what I am sure will be similar forest issues.

PARA.TAB: I wanted to make a contribution to the debate because what we are witnessing is a not unique thing in Australian political history; it is, indeed, the birth of a quango. I have been making a study of quangos for some time—

TALK.START.PARA: —A small, furry animal?

—A quango is not a small, furry animal that lives in a hollow log somewhere. It is actually a quasi-autonomous national government organisation. Far from being an endangered species, it is something that is growing very rapidly in Australia. Indeed, the research done by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which publishes an annual list of so-called Commonwealth bodies, known more colloquially as quangos, has shown that during the 10 years of the Labor government the number of quangos has expanded by nearly 100 per cent.
—You are talking to the legislation, are you?

—I will be in a roundabout way. One of the problems with the establishment of these bodies is that once they are actually created it is very hard to find out where they were created and they seem to have a life that goes on forever, unlike trees and animals of the forest.

PARA.TAB: I refer to what I thought was a funny quote from a book on quangos. It is by a person called Harriet Beecher Stowe. I presume it is a work of fiction. I do not know; I am not that literate. The book talks about the birth of quangos. There are something like 800 quangos in Australia at the moment—that is federal government quangos, not taking into account the state ones. The quote reads:

SPEECH.PARA: `Who was your mother?' `Never had none,' said the child, with another grin. `Never had any mother? What do you mean? Where were you born?' `Never was born,' persisted Topsy; never had no father, nor mother, nor nothin'. I was raised by a speculator.' . . . `Do you know who made you?' `Nobody as I knows on,' said the child, with a short laugh.. . I `spect I growed.'

There is not doubt today about the birth of this quango. This legislation is being passed by the parliament and it will indeed impose some burdens on the industry. It will create a corporation. That corporation will have members of the board, it will have secretarial services and, like most other quangos in Australian history, and indeed in the history of governments around the world, it will tend to grow.

PARA.TAB: There are some redeeming features which have encouraged me to vote for this bill—apart from the fact that I do not want to make a scene by crossing the floor and voting against my party room—which the minister has referred to in his second reading speech. One of the redeeming features of this legislation is that the second reading speech contains a commitment—I have yet to see it in the bill; it may well be there—to ensure that there is a review of the operations of the corporation after 1995-96.

I cannot see a sunset clause in the legislation. I am not particularly impressed by the operation of sunset clauses in relation to quangos anyway. Even though sunset clauses saw the demise of a few quangos over the last couple of years, some 200 more replaced them, so the growth of quangos goes on.

Another redeeming feature of this legislation is that this quango will be required to make a report to the parliament annually. That means that all parliamentarians can indeed keep an eye on the activities of the new corporation and ensure that it is not wasting government money or the money of those who indeed contribute the levies.

It needs also to be noted that the industry has called for the creation of this. However, I must point out that I do not think that, where an industry calls for the creation of a quango, it necessarily means that that quango is a good idea.

I certainly do not pick on the forestry industries group itself because in my dealings with it I have found it to be a very genuine, well-intentioned representative of its industry, but there is an enormous incentive for industry groups which are private, voluntary and cooperative to become quangos because they get given money by the government, they get offices paid for by the government and contributed to by their membership and they really do become part of the state.

It is a lot cosier being in the cradle of the state than being out there trying to get levies collected voluntarily, going around trying to convince the members that they should contribute to research. Altogether, things become a lot harder if you are out there in the cold, hard, voluntary, cooperative area. It is always nice to be part of a cosy quango where you are guaranteed some funding from the government and where the levy is collected statutorily by the force of the sort of legislation we are passing today.

Since I have made a commitment to my whip and I am a person of my word, I will not go on. I conclude by saying that I think the growth of quangos generally in Australia is an area that requires further examination by the parliament. I know that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is a heavily burdened committee. The committee system in this parliament is continually being stressed by reductions of funding from the executive and I do not think that the finance and public administration committee can do a lot more work on this to actually solve the problem of quangos.

I wrote a letter to the Auditor-General just last week to suggest that he may find this an area that is worth while to study. There is an enormous range of quangos that chew up millions and millions of dollars of taxpayers' money. Many of those quangos do not report to parliament or even to the minister and I think there needs to be a lot more work done on how money is spent in this way. Having said that, I will conclude my remarks and leave matters more germane to the bill to my colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of legislation—the forest industries research bills—is designed to establish funding mechanisms for research into forest industries and related areas. This commitment to research is outlined in the national forest policy statement, which was signed by the Commonwealth government and all state governments, except that of Tasmania, in December 1992. The document exists largely because the Commonwealth government failed to obtain the support of this parliament for the resource security legislation which was debated in this chamber earlier in 1992. The document was initially negotiated secretly between governments and industry and ultimately reflects this lack of commitment to public consultation and to concerns about conservation issues.

PARA.TAB: The bills before us for consideration today establish an administrative framework and funding mechanism for the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. Levies will be paid by importers and exporters of unprocessed wood and local mill owners who receive unprocessed logs, with the Commonwealth matching funding at a rate of one Commonwealth dollar for every two dollars raised from the domestic industry.

On the face of it, this may seem a reasonable proposition for the forest industries and for the Commonwealth government to be pursuing. My concern relates to the concept of charging for forest industry research on the basis of the value of logs extracted from our native forests with no apparent differentiation between a log extracted from a high conservation native forest and one extracted from a plantation or agroforestry operation.

Effectively, the destruction of our native forests will be secured and will be used to fund research into sustainable options for the forest industries—an extraordinary piece of logic. The irony of charging for resources at a minimal level, as in a levy, and adding to this Commonwealth funding, is that it can provide tacit permission for the stripping of those resources to the enormous benefit of the forest industries and the enormous detriment of our country's natural resources.

The motivation underlying forest policy and practice must be challenged. There is no incentive here for the industry to move to an ecologically sustainable basis. My colleague Senator Margetts will expand on this point.

If handled properly, this research program could assist in the movement of the Australian timber and forest industry to an ecologically sustainable basis. The ecological aspect, however, needs to be stressed. The continuation of any practices that involve the destruction of old-growth or wilderness forests is not ecologically sustainable. In my home state of Western Australia for example, the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management is logging many areas of forest that are of high conservation value. Some of those areas were identified in a joint assessment of the southern forest region by CALM and the Australian Heritage Commission in the late 1980s.

I have recently written to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) enclosing aerial photographic evidence of extensive CALM logging in one of the forest blocks identified as having high conservation value and asking her to investigate the extent of this practice in Western Australia. To date, I have had no reply.

The practice of clear-felling large areas of native forests on relatively short rotations and encouraging regrowth using mechanical or chemical thinning is also not ecologically sustainable, particularly where the native forest that is destroyed is being used for woodchips or charcoal. Sadly, the karri forests of the south-west of Western Australia are all being used as woodchips and the jarrah forests are rapidly being used for charcoal or `activated carbon', to use a euphemism.

These practices are widespread in the Australian forest industries. This is outrageous in the context of the stated principles of the national forest policy statement, which stress the need for the protection of old-growth and wilderness forests and the management of all native forest areas in an ecologically sustainable manner.

The principal point I wish to make in this context is that the national forest policy statement also contains extensive provisions relating to the protection of high conservation native forests. The statement outlines a methodology for establishing an agreed set of criteria on which to base a reserve system and to protect those reserved forest areas. So far—this is referred to on page 10 of the document—the government is committed to the establishment of criteria. But the criteria, which it is claimed will be based on principles of comprehensiveness, adequacy and representativeness, have not been released for public debate or consideration. These criteria must be released publicly.

I also suggest that the imbalance in relation to approaching the national forest policy that these bills represent must be addressed. Those criteria are very valuable and should precede any kind of levy that is being charged on forest products.

The strategy to protect old-growth forests contains five basic elements. One of them is an interim provision that requires the state agencies responsible for forest management to place an embargo on any forest management activities that may significantly affect those areas of high conservation value that are likely to be placed into a reserve system. This policy of setting up a forest industries research levy is one of those practices that potentially could be endangering these high conservation areas.

A moratorium is required in the strategy contained in the national forest policy statement to protect old-growth forests and wilderness. The embargo is not being adhered to, nor is the Commonwealth government taking any action to ensure that the conservation provisions of the national forest policy statement are respected by the state governments which are signatories to the statement.

The Commonwealth government has the power, through the constitution and through its funding of many aspects of forest conservation and timber industry research, to force state governments to adhere to these provisions. I urge the government to reconsider its rash action in supporting these bills, which actually subsidise state governments for raping our forests.

It appears that these powers are only to be used in respect of industrial relations matters. It is this inconsistency that is of great concern to the conservation movement. However laudable the research work that is the subject of the bills before us today, it will not help the establishment of an ecologically sustainable timber industry in this country without the implementation of the conservation provisions.

The funding of the research program that is the subject of these bills will be at the expense of our native forests. Funding can continue only if the forest industry continues to log native forests, including some old growth and wilderness areas. This is totally unacceptable and is at odds with the fundamental principles of the national forest policy statement. In the light of these serious inconsistencies, the Greens (WA) will not be supporting this package of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the coalition—the Liberal and National parties—will be supporting this package of forest industries research bills. The legislation is not quite everything that we want it to be, but it is a start. The most important thing to recognise is that the forest industries are a primary industry and, therefore, deserve treatment on the same basis as other primary industries.

PARA.TAB: Research is absolutely fundamental. Research into better forest practices and different varieties of timber for use in plantations is absolutely critical to having a good forest industry. That is why I am very surprised tonight that the Australian Democrats and the Greens have signified to the chamber that they will not be supporting this package of legislation.

Certainly, if they wish us to continue logging just native forests and not go into plantation areas, I could understand the logical consistency of saying, `Well, we are not going to support this package'. But the Greens and the Democrats have on numerous occasions said that they want us to move more and more into plantation timber. It has to be understood that when a plantation is put in, that investment will not mature for at least 10 years. In the case of some very slow growing hardwood timbers, that investment may not mature for 40, 50, 60, 70 or 80 years.

Nobody in his right mind would make that sort of investment unless he can be guaranteed that the timber that he is putting in is the right timber for the area, that it will get the right yields and, ultimately, that the species that will be grown will be in demand when the trees reach maturity. To say to somebody, `We want you to put aside $3,000 per hectare to put in plantation timber in the first year, pay the ongoing costs until that timber reaches maturity and then have no certainty that you will have the right trees at the right place at the right time or that the trees will grow into a marketable form of timber'—one tree which grows well in one place may not grow well in another—is a nonsense.

It is necessary that these bills be passed if we are to have a viable plantation timber industry. Those who oppose this bill do not advance the green agenda; in fact, they set that green agenda back quite a way. Unless we can develop a sustainable, productive and profitable—`profitable' is the key word—plantation timber industry, we will see the continued logging of native forests. We will see logging of native forests on a much greater scale than would happen if we could give some impetus to the plantation timber industry.

Other problems face the plantation timber industry. I suppose that the biggest problem is security. Everybody in this chamber has to understand that nobody will plant trees, wait 25 years for them to reach maturity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy years in South Australia.

—Some of the faster growing hardwood species in Queensland take about 25 years. I take Senator Coulter's interjection. If we want to wait 70 years, it is even more idiotic to expect people to make that sort of investment if they have no security over the resource when it comes time to harvest those trees. People will not put money into plantation timber unless they can be guaranteed that, when the trees come to maturity, they will be allowed to log that timber.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a number of cases in New South Wales where people have put in private coupes of timber.
