The trees have grown to maturity and some of the extreme—I will not call them environmentalists—preservationists are now saying, `Look, irrespective of the fact that there were no trees there before you put those trees in with your own money, that you have waited for them to mature and they are now ready, we do not want you to log them because we have found some spurious reason to stop that'. If people want to have a plantation timber industry, they have to be fair dinkum and willing to offer resource security.

One of the other problems facing the industry—I hate to tickle the ribs of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) over this, but I feel I have to say it—is that, at the moment, the government is not issuing the scope and guidelines for regional assessments that are required under the forest policy statement which we had last year. Until that goes ahead, it will be very difficult to get the sort of investment that we need.

There is much that we can do and should be doing with plantation timber. I am a big supporter of it. I am very green in that respect because I believe it is a great industry. Senator Murphy would probably back me up on this. In terms of people employed per hectare in primary industry in this country, there is no more labour intensive industry than the silviculture industry. It will be of enormous benefit for us to get these things going as quickly as possible.

In North Queensland, for example, there will be immense benefit if we can get security for people's investment, if we can get the guidelines for regional assessments. There is scope for the federal and state governments to work together in areas abutting the World Heritage area—areas that I think you know very well, Mr Acting Deputy President—to create a special type of land title which is a freehold forestry title. As it has been suggested to me, that would work on the basis of people converting existing freehold title which abuts World Heritage areas into freehold forestry, with an absolute guarantee that they will be able to harvest that timber as and when they are ready. That creates a voluntary buffer zone arrangement which protects the World Heritage areas but which also gives absolute security to the resource for the people who want to make the investment. Those are the sorts of creative things that we can and should be doing.

We have to look at improving the growth of hardwood plantation timber in this country. Studies done by the Resource Assessment Commission clearly show that in 20 years time we will start to see the beginning of an enormous gap between production and demand for hardwood sawlogs. In order to meet that demand in 20, 25, 30 or 40 years time, we have to start the planning and the investment now. That is why this bill is dreadfully important.

I say to those who signified to the chamber tonight that they are going to oppose the bill: do not do it. All you will do is set back the cause of the genuine environmentalists. You will set back job opportunities for people who work in the timber industry; you will set back the opportunity of people in regional Australia to actually gain productive income from the land; and you will set back the opportunity for us to do things with the land other than split it up for subdivision and put houses on it. In many cases, we are talking about very fertile, very productive soil.

I have a very firm belief that we waste the bounties which God has given us by taking good soil and good rainfall and putting houses on two-acre blocks when we could, in fact, be putting that land and that rainfall to productive use in primary industry. The forest industries, although they have not been recognised as they should be, are a great primary industry for Australia and one which has a lot of potential for us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of comments in relation to some of Senator O'Chee's remarks. A number of industries in Australia receive 150 per cent research rebates. Here we are raising money at the cost of the demise of old-growth forests so we can fund plantation research. In Western Australia, the department of conservation and land management has known for years about the potential for harvesting in sustainable ways, about the potential for agroforestry, but it has not done anything about it.

PARA.TAB: In New South Wales, softwood plantations have been languishing for years. They have the potential to generate employment—the potential to be used. They have not been thinned properly, they have not been serviced properly and they have not been trimmed. Perhaps, as a timber resource, they are becoming less and less valuable. The research has been there. A lot of the information, as Senator Coulter has said, has been around for a long time. What is lacking is the political will to make the decisions which really lead to an ecologically sustainable industry.

As my colleague Senator Chamarette indicated earlier, we have had major concerns in relation to the package of forest bills which are before us today. One of our principal concerns is that the industry research aspect of the national forest policy statement is being implemented without a complementary commitment to the conservation provisions of the statement. In addition, and applied to that point, is the ludicrous implication of the funding mechanism—that research into a supposedly ecologically sustainable forest industry is, in part, being funded through the destruction of native forests. So here we are. We have no guarantee that the money which is being raised in this way is going to the purpose to which it is supposed to be going. It not specified anywhere in the legislation. The Greens and the conservation movement are united in their opposition to this proposed funding mechanism.

In relation to some of the points that Senator O'Chee was making, if our timber resources were valued for their true value—their true economic value if we are looking at them as timber resources—our uses of them would be a great deal different from what they are now. We would be creating a great deal more employment. We would be making different decisions which would perhaps lead to more ecologically sustainable choices in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The forest industries research bills do not appear to contain any levy differential between logs removed from native forests, sometimes of high conservation value, and logs removed from plantations or agroforestry operations. The logical conclusion to that is that if any kind of tax of that nature does not discriminate it is obvious to pull out the higher value logs. Whilst this may be done by regulations, there does not appear to have been a commitment by the government in this regard. I understand that the regulations will be the subject of negotiation between the office of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the forestry industry. I fear that there will be little support from industry for such a price difference. In many cases the companies are involved in both plantations and native forest logging. If such a differential were established by regulation it would assist in encouraging a move to ecologically sustainable forestry.

PARA.TAB: Ironically, this commitment to the ecologically sustainable management of our native forests is incorporated into the national forest policy statement. It is being blatantly ignored by this government as well as by the state governments which are signatories to the agreement.

The fact remains that many options are available for the forest industry to move to a truly sustainable basis in this country. Not only will this provide opportunities for employment for future generations but also in the short-term will assist in halting the decline in employment in the forest industries. This decline in employment has been due to the increasing capitalisation of the industry and the elimination of many of the smaller and, should I say, more efficient mills.

An ecologically sustainable forest industry should be based on plantations on already cleared land, agroforestry, smaller timber mills, small scale environmentally friendly pulp mills and other downstream processing operations, such as ecotourism and the furniture and craft industries. All of these operations acknowledge the need to protect the ecological integrity of our precious and unique native forests.

In recent times, I have had the opportunity to visit various regional centres in the south west of Western Australia to see first hand the excellent and often unfunded work being carried out by people committed to an ecologically sustainable forest industry. On one farming property near Bridgetown the farmer has introduced agroforestry onto his property both as an additional cash crop but also to assist in maintaining the ecological integrity of the farm. He has virtually maintained the same stocking rates by incorporating 50 to 20 metre gaps between rows of trees. As a consequence, he has also recorded astonishing growth rates in the plantation crop. This is a truly win win situation. The establishment of agroforestry operations such as this, together with the expansion of plantations on already cleared land, will provide the feed stock for other value adding industries to assist the regional economies of the south west as well as many other regions in Australia.

I am aware, for example, of a proposal being developed for a pulp mill in the south west of Western Australia. The Greens would support the concept of value adding, but agree with the concerns of conservationists that there is not currently sufficient plantation feed stock to operate such a mill. The use of native forest timber in this regard is neither acceptable nor ecologically sustainable. The Greens would advocate the establishment of a few smaller pulp mills located centrally to various regional plantation sources. In addition, the pulp mills would need to be close loop and based on a non-chlorine bleaching process. This would be achieved if plantation timber were used as feed stock.

The value of ecotourism should not be underestimated. For example, in the south west of Western Australia many more people are employed in the tourist industry than in the forest and timber industry. One of the main attractions for many of these tourists are the unique karri and jarrah forests that are found in Western Australia. Tourists do not travel thousands of miles to see clear-felled areas where forests once stood or the uniform ecologically imbalanced regrowth that is encouraged in its place.

The craft and fine furniture industries are also major contributors to the tourist industry and to regional economies. In Pemberton, in the south west of Western Australia, there is a fine example of a craft gallery run on ecologically sound principles. The owners have encouraged the use of mill offcuts and timber that would normally be burnt by mill owners as scrap for use in craft and furniture operations. Wood chippers are continuing to burn much of that waste despite its use as habitat or in fine craft highly value added goods. The building that houses this craft shop uses many timbers traditionally shunned by builders and the timber industry for structural and other purposes.

All of these examples point to the opportunities that are available for moving the forest and timber industries on to a truly sustainable basis. Research into these options should, however, not be funded by cutting the native forests that we should be protecting. It is on this basis that the Greens will not be supporting this package of bills.

We trust that the government will consult more widely in the future before proposing unsustainable policy principles such as those outlined in these bills. The government has given us only words so far in relation to ecologically sustainable development. It talks so often of an economic imperative, but there is a far more fundamental imperative—the ecological one. A conservation movement slogan says `No environment, no economy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the forest industries bills on behalf of the coalition. These bills seek to establish the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. I am very much in favour of research and development and have been personally involved in such work during my time in private industry. Tonight I want to address the key issues of this industry, and in particular the comments that have been made in recent weeks by the Greens and the Democrats seeking to denigrate this industry. The forest industry is one of the largest industries in Australia. It employs about 75,000 people, including the manufacturing side of it, has a turnover of about $10 billion and, as mentioned earlier tonight, imports of about $2.4 billion in 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: Over the past 10 years the industry's growth prospects have been sacrificed by the Labor government in favour of the politics of suburbia in Melbourne and Sydney and by offering arrangements with the anti-development lobby against this industry. The industry is dependent on a large forest estate. The estate consists of about one million hectares of plantation forest—that forest is increasing by 50,000 hectares per year—and about seven million hectares of native forest, which are managed on a sustained yield, long rotation basis. The forest estate is not decreasing; in fact, it is increasing in a substantial way via plantations.

I was very disappointed to hear the comments made by the Greens and by Senator Coulter. Today, yesterday and last week they were making claims about native forests being destroyed, criticising the woodchip industry and claiming that all native forest wood based industries are subsidised. Given Senator Coulter's science background, I would have thought he would have taken the trouble to obtain the facts.

The industry has been subject to much unsubstantiated criticism over many years. In 1990 Prime Minister Hawke established the Resource Assessment Commission with the aim of seeking out the facts of the matter, including whether the native forests were being abused or not, whether they were well managed and whether they should be used for conservation or multiple use, including wood. Over two years the Resource Assessment Commission took over 500 submissions, produced 33 consultants reports and in 1992 published over 1,500 pages of report. In essence, that report concluded that early this century state governments founded forestry departments or commissions to stop the further clearing of the best of the native forests. The forests had been cleared for agriculture.

The RAC said it could find no evidence to support a cessation of logging of native forests in Australia. The native forests are being managed on a sustained yield basis. It also said that the managed forestry operations in Australia have not been linked to the extinction of a single plant or animal species. Yet the country's `extinction record' is continually proffered as grounds for the industry's closure. Unremitting references to the `ancient' and `pristine' misrepresent the biological resilience of the eucalyptus species and wrongly portrays forests as being a static entity. Pre- and post-European history shows us that we have been subject to constant natural and human disturbance for anything up to 40,000 years.

The fact that more than half of the 10 million hectares of forest in parks and conservation areas—contrast that with the seven million that are available for multiple use, including wood—were logged in the past is testament to both the resilience of the forests and to the minimal impact of logging.

Tonight and on previous occasions Senator Coulter made the erroneous claim that the wood industry based on the native forest is subsidised. Native forests that are owned by the public—in other words, by the state governments—are managed for multiple use. This means that they are managed for water, conservation, recreation, fire protection and wood production. Senator Coulter is claiming that the wood is subsidised. However, he is neglecting the cost of managing those forests if they were converted to parks and not used for wood. The facts are that the cost of managing those forests for wood, recreation, conservation of the eco-system and fire protection is very little different on an area basis compared to also including wood production, which at least makes a significant contribution to the economics of running those forests. But to say that the native forests are being subsidised by the community is quite erroneous. In fact, it is the other way around: wood production from the publicly owned native forests of Australia is making a substantial contribution to the general community for managing those public forests for other multiple uses.

The other point that Senator Coulter made—it was also referred to by our Green senators—related to wastage. Yet at the same time he wanted to criticise the woodchip industry. If we want to run native forests on a sustained yield basis and have them replaced on a sustained yield basis, we have to make use of the material that is there and get rid of it so that a new crop can be established. The woodchip industry has been the saviour of the recovery of the native forests of Australia, which were downgraded late last century and early this century by the sawmilling industry, which attacked those forests and, by selective logging, took out the better trees and gradually downgraded the forests.

I have been allotted very little time tonight but wish to make a couple of final points. The Industry Commission's report on this industry is currently before the government. The Industry Commission report pointed out that investment by this industry is expected to be $1.7 billion over the next 10 years if there is no change in policy by the governments. However, if we can agree to a forest policy strategy and security of property rights for the industry, the Industry Commission pointed out that the investment would probably double to over $3 billion during the next 10 years.

Finally, I support the research and development aspect. It is very worth while. It will help the smaller firms in the industry achieve international competitiveness, and that is the key for all Australians. I support the bills and commend them to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to follow Senator Gibson in this debate on the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills. I should say that there are few people in Australia with the commanding knowledge of the timber industry that he has.

PARA.TAB: The bill will create the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. The establishment of this corporation is essential as it will play a major role in helping the forestry industry focus on much needed research and development. Australia imports more than $2.4 billion worth of timber products annually, with exports of only about $775 million. Put another way, we import about four times the value of the forest products we currently export. About 70 per cent of our imports are pulp and paper products. This could only be regarded as unsatisfactory and the sooner a new pulp mill or two is built, the better.

Continuous interference by lobby groups has caused governments over a long period to make erratic decisions on forestry, creating a massive loss of confidence within the industry. This has had a destabilising effect on the industry, as is evident by the huge trade deficit. Australia should not have a trade deficit in any area of primary production, but it has in this industry.

All major investigations into the forestry industry, including the Resource Assessment Commission's 1992 forest and timber inquiry, have highlighted the need for a coordinated, efficient research program. All groups agree that further research is vital to boost productivity and value adding processing in forest and wood product industries. This new corporation will provide a vehicle for a coordinated approach to national research priorities. It will have an industry based framework. It is important that the corporation is run by the industry for the industry, and it will be.

The corporation will commission, administer and subsequently evaluate research into wood production, extraction, processing, economics and marketing. It will also be sensitive to the environment. Its charter will include the ecological and environmental impacts of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations. Because of Australia's small market and the need for scale, we must find our own way, develop the unique technology and reach unconventional solutions. There must be a strong emphasis on product quality and reliability. Increased value added production in Australia can be potentially realised through domestic market growth, import replacement and increasing exports into growing foreign markets.

Thirty years ago the CSIRO had approximately 30 scientists working on timber research and development. The massive cut in CSIRO funds has meant that little or no research and development is now available for the industry. With many manufacturers actively engaged in extensive research into and marketing of alternatives and wood substitutes, timber products are suffering significantly. For the timber industry to keep up with world best practice, this is much needed legislation. However, we must not lose sight of the fact that the industry's future must always rely on resource security. I noted what Senator O'Chee said in this regard and I agree with him 100 percent.

Small companies within the industry are unable to secure their futures because of the short-term supply contracts issued by the government. Investment in new equipment and upgrading their operations is virtually impossible under the existing arrangements. This must also be addressed by the government if we are to have a viable industry.

The coalition sees the timber industry as a growth industry with the ability to reduce our trade deficit and create more jobs, especially in the value adding of our products. We are determined for the industry to prosper in a balanced and responsible way. With a turnover of more than $10 billion the forest products industry is one of this nation's biggest resource based industries. It has evolved as Australia's second largest manufacturing industry after the processed foods and tobacco sector. It is of immense importance to many regional communities. It is of immense importance to Australia. Let no-one forget that.

The forest industry provides employment for over 100,000 people directly and indirectly. This is an industry vital to the people of the electorates of Page, Eden-Monaro and Richmond in my state of New South Wales. It provides jobs in many small communities whose very existence rely on the timber industry. This legislation will help to secure those jobs.

New South Wales has a timber industry that is managed efficiently, despite the criticism levelled by radical conservation groups. I see these bills as another step in delivering an industry attuned to market requirements. Therefore I have pleasure in supporting the bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills. I do not intend to go into great detail about what the bills do because I think they have been spelled out quite substantially by other speakers. Very clearly, these are very important measures in so far as the Australian timber industry is concerned. They take a very important step, probably one that is long overdue, with regard to having a capacity for R&D that is primarily paid for by both manufacturers and importers, users of timber et cetera in this country.

PARA.TAB: It is not a comprehensive package that deals with the national forest policy statement; therefore I do not believe there is a great requirement for it to address every issue, particularly conservation issues outlined in the national forest policy statement. What it will do is provide industry and government with a mechanism to look at the industry from the point of view of developing it in a way that is sustainable and, hopefully, will create further downstream processing and further value adding of this country's forest resources.

I would like to separate those two points. Downstream processing is somewhat different from value adding. If we are going to further process the timber that we harvest from our forests, then I am sure that it will lead to greater employment. Some of those things have been alluded to by a number of speakers, in particular the Democrats and the Greens who talked about some of the smaller sectors of the industry, and that is an important factor from my point of view.

The board that will be set up will have a selection panel. It will be chaired by Megan Cornelius, who is a ministerial appointment, and other members of the panel will be appointed by industry. With regard to its reporting and even its success in the longer term, it is required to report to the parliament and I am quite sure that the government will be very interested in its success, particularly as it relates to employment.

I have some difficulty with the way in which this debate has been used by some speakers to talk about other issues. I do not think I could allow those other issues to go unnoticed or not comment on them. Firstly, I would like to pick up the question of resource security. Some opposition senators chose to take the opportunity to blame the government for its inability to bring about resource security.

We ought to have a look at who voted on resource security and where they voted. Regardless of whether we believed resource security was the right measure for certain aspects of the industry, the fact was that the government proposed resource security for the industry—maybe not for all of the industry but certainly for part of it—and those opposite did not support it. That is why it went down. So there is no point in those opposite coming in here trying to blame the government over an issue which they voted against—voting with the very people that they have condemned tonight for taking certain points and raising certain issues with respect to matters that are important to them.

With regard to the industry as a whole, quite frankly, I believe that it has a lot of cleaning up to do. We have got a long way to go with regard to how this industry utilises the resources available to it, particularly in the area of employment. In the Asia-Pacific region, it is known that there will be a shortage of timber supplies of large proportions going into the next decade. Therefore, we as a country, and the industry within this country, need to take account of that and make sure that we maximise the opportunities available to us—both in exports and in the employment that can be generated in the industry—so that we utilise the timber in the best possible way.

The issue of inquiries into this industry has been raised. I come from a state that has probably had more inquiries than any other in this country. I have sometimes wondered at the wisdom of the government in having further inquiries, and I have different views on the various inquiries over time. My knowledge of the industry has increased over a long period now and I still feel that the industry needs to lift its game. It has certainly improved, but we still have a long way to go. What really disappoints me today is when I see the misuse of a resource that could generate employment in this country. It is a very important industry in terms of employment. It does have the capacity, above all other resource based industries, to generate employment. We should be vigilant in terms of seeking to maximise those opportunities.
I heard comments from Senator Tambling that integrated forest harvesting was really the only way to go. Rather than debate the point, I merely point out that that is not necessarily the case.

I turn to the introduction of these levies through these bills. It seemed to me as though there was some concept coming from members of the opposition that the government was forcing this upon the industry. In fact, the industry sought this measure—it wanted it and it will largely be responsible for it. It is wrong of opposition senators to come in here and claim, `Here is the good old government forcing upon industry some costly exercise', when in the main we will be doing the funding on a two for one basis. That ought to be realised by opposition members because it certainly is acknowledged by the industry.

Senator Coulter said that the Australian Democrats will withhold their support until the government gets serious about the issues that I assume are important to the Democrats. I wonder what Senator Coulter's view would be if the government and the opposition came in here when a certain aspect relating to conservation arising out of the national forest policy statement was being put in the form of a bill in this place and we said, `Well, we're not happy about that. We're going to hold out until such time as we get our little bit squared off'.

With regard to Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts saying that nothing is being done in respect of conservation, that is not true. A process is being put in place between the Commonwealth and the states—which will probably be finalised by the end of this year—that will still be able to meet the requirements of the national forest policy statement with respect to the 1995 date.

Turning to the claims about there being no political will to save Australia's old-growth and native forests, Senator Coulter obviously has not seen or taken note of the efforts of this government with respect to a range of forests around this country. In particular, I can talk of my own state of Tasmania where we have almost 30 per cent of the forests now in reserves. That is not to say there is anything wrong with that process because it is important for us to continue to make sure that we do all the things that are environmentally sound. But it is wrong to come in here and make claims that are not supported by the facts.

I think Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette raised a question about taxing native forests higher than we would tax plantation forests. These bills are about sustainable development of an industry. It will not bring an end to logging of native or old-growth forests if we do not have these bills. The fact is that the levies arising out of these bills, and in particular those to domestic production, will be on the current production levels. There will not be an increase, and there will not be a decrease as a result of not having these levies.

I noted with interest the claim made by Senator Margetts about pulp mills. There is more than ample stock arising out of the harvesting of native forests, and plantation forests for that matter, for the purposes of providing for and meeting the needs of our domestic sawmilling industry—that is, the residual wood—to feed three pulp mills in this country. We only have to look at Victoria to see the massive amount of waste that goes on. I find it unfortunate that the conservation movement has opposed strenuously the utilisation of wood that is currently being burnt. Not only would it serve the purpose of getting some further processing of that wood but also it would create an opportunity for more employment.

The important point arising out of the bills is that the research and development work that will be conducted will ensure a range of options for this industry. Certainly I, as a government member for whatever time I may be here, will be watching very keenly and trying to ensure that we maximise the opportunities arising out of having such a board in place. I hope that it will add to the further downstream processing of this country's resource. For that reason, I endorse the bills and urge honourable senators to vote for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Tambling in this debate on the Forest Industries Research Levy Bill and cognate bills. A little earlier tonight Senator Gibson also made some very important remarks. He is actually someone who knows more about the forest industries in this place than most. He is someone who has played a part in a constructive way and an administrative way since he has been in this place.

PARA.TAB: I cannot recall any other industry that, as Senator Tambling has suggested, has been scrutinised or called on to justify itself more than the forestry industry. There is an attitude amongst some groups that, whatever the results of any inquiry and no matter how open state governments are about their operations and methodology, the only option for management of our forests is no logging. Despite all the evidence, there will always be people who want forests to remain intact, untouched and unproductive, but we just cannot go on that way. We have a renewable resource which, if logged properly, can go on for many years. This group of people who do not want any logging is the same group which has no alternative answer as to where income will be generated for towns and communities that depend on a viable timber industry. All too often, this is the same group of people who depend on other taxpayers, through the public purse, to finance their activities.

These objections continue to be made, despite all the evidence which shows that Australia needs to increase productivity and value adding—which just about everyone in this place agrees with generally—in the forests and wood product industries within a framework of ecological sustainability. I have said in this place many times before that we have to have production and protection going hand-in-hand. We cannot just lock up everything and say that we are not going to have any production.

There is enormous potential within Australia for expansion of the timber industry, because Australia only supplies two-thirds of its domestic requirements. In other words, we import more than $2.4 billion worth of timber and export only $775 million worth of product. That is unlikely to change in terms of increased domestic production while we have such instability within the industry.

I was talking earlier tonight with Senator Gibson about what really is needed. We have to have resource security. People have to be able to log a native forest in a sustainable way. If we put in a plantation we need resource security so that if somebody at some later stage finds a long-footed potoroo on that plantation, logging will not be stopped, which is quite a possibility with the way things are.

There needs to be real security of investment, just as we need it for mining and agriculture. If we do not have it, how do we get the investment and the people wanting to produce a product that we all use? It is sitting around us here now. We cannot say we cannot log any forests because we would have nothing to sit on because there would be no seats; we would have no roofs over our heads and no houses to live; we would have nothing. We have to have security for the people in the timber industry so that they can go ahead and produce the product which helps us all. We are not going to get investment without that firm direction from the government or a commitment that will protect that investment from the whim of future governments.

By the same token, we have to look after the forests and make sure it is done on a sustainable basis. I have not yet met anyone in the forest industry who has not been a very good conservationist. People in the forest industry are conservationists themselves. We have a renewable resource in the timber industry. If people on the other side want to laugh about it and think that trees do not grow, they should look at how quickly the trees have grown around this Parliament House in just a little while. Trees can grow very quickly and it can be done on a sustainable basis.

The arguments that the environmentalists put to prevent logging of native forests are made in isolation from world realities. While Australia continues to under supply its own market, imports of timber from endangered forest areas in other countries continue unabated. If we were real conservationists, we would rather use timber from our well managed local native forests than have it come out of other forests around the world. In a national sense we create an imbalance in trade and in a global sense we destroy the environment and that is not sound management of our planet.

The much used slogan, `Think globally, act locally' has not translated well when it comes to Australia's timber and paper needs. Regarding resource security, the Resource Assessment Commission's inquiry into options for the use of Australia's forest and timber resources concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . security of investment for the wood and wood products industry is essential to the future of a competitive industry. Its preferred approach included provision for compensation.

It also argued that the benefit to the community from using native forests and plantations could be increased by providing certainty to industry, which I have already discussed, and security of access to resources. On plantations, it argued:

The Inquiry found that the extent to which wood from plantations can replace wood from native forests is limited by past rates of planting. Further, unless the community is prepared to accept significant dislocation of regional industry and employment it will not be feasible to accelerate the replacement of native hardwoods with softwood resources.

We have had that inquiry and that is from the Resource Assessment Commission's annual report 1992-93. That needs to be understood by those who oppose the forest industry. The only alternative is to encourage people to use less timber, and that is hardly appropriate as a stimulus to our economy.

PARA.TAB: Those who defend the forest industries acknowledge freely that not always have our native forests been well managed, but like so many other industries in Australia, including farming, we have learnt by our mistakes. The Forest Protection Society acknowledges that freely. Earlier this year, in the introduction to a very good book of that society, its National Director, Robyn Loydell, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Forest Protection Society . . . does not harbour pretences about being a scientific organisation.
It said later:

We all know that managed wood production is a form of forest disturbance. Whether it is within the capacity of our forests to cope with such selective disturbance for the benefit of humans is the question which should be the central focus of future debate in this country.
Perhaps if this central issue had been addressed 20 years ago, much of the pain which has followed many ill-conceived forest closures could have been avoided.
The FPS commissioned a study by Dr Peter Attiwill, a quote from which I think is well worth reading out. He quoted from T.C. Whitmore, writing on tropical forests, who said:

. . . (they) are a renewable resource which can be utilized and still retain their diversity and richness for mankind's continuing benefit; but only if we care to learn enough about how they work, and also if, as has been repeatedly stated, utilisation takes place within the limits of the forest's inherent dynamic processes.
That is really about using a forest to its best ability and using the forests so that the renewable resource can be used.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Forest Protection Society for the job that it does; I believe that its 9,000-odd members around Australia have really done a lot to make sure the debate in Australia is much more balanced. The annual summer protests that have become almost a standard entertainment in the south-eastern forests for school holiday tourists are as predictable as they are phoney. At the end of the day, they do not increase anyone's knowledge of the forest industry. They cost the industry and they merely exacerbate the combustible situation with loggers who are trying to earn a living in a tough occupation, and who are tired of being provoked.

The forest industries in Australia are and can continue to be a valuable economic and environmental asset if they are allowed to get on with the job. These bills will assist the industries to continue to manage our forests; they will increase our knowledge of how best to do that; and they will help to create a much needed investment environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I decided to put my name on the list tonight after hearing a lot of the nonsense that was being spoken by the coalition senators. I think the general thrust of their argument is that forests are only about one thing and that is timber production and let us forget about everything else. Although the Australian Democrats support the principle of value adding, we do not support value adding of logs taken from old-growth forests. Whilst the forestry industry continues to log old-growth forests and wilderness areas the Democrats will not support any measures to enhance value adding where the timbers are obtained from old-growth forests of significance.

PARA.TAB: The slaughter of our old-growth forests this spring and summer will occur on an unprecedented scale if nothing is done to stop it. The Democrats will not condone the further destruction of these forests by supporting the passage of these bills. Senator Coulter, who spoke before me, pointed out that the Commonwealth and the states, except Tasmania, signed the national forest policy at the end of last year. That policy requires state forest agencies to avoid activities that significantly affect old-growth forests and wilderness areas until assessments have been carried out and a reservation system established on public land by 1995. The way we are going in many areas there will be very little, if anything, left by 1995.

The states are breaching the national forest policy in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and Queensland. In Tasmania, logging is continuing apace in both old-growth forests of significance and wilderness areas. The states are obviously flouting the agreement. The Commonwealth government clearly has the responsibility to do something about it.

The first real test of the Commonwealth's integrity on this issue was late last year. A few days after the policy was signed, the then Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, gave approval for export woodchipping licences. This decision led to the destruction of significant areas of high conservation value forest. The next test will come up in a few weeks when the new Minister for Resources, Mr Lee, must decide on woodchip export licence conditions for another year. If Mr Lee does not make the right decision, we will once again see major blockades and campaigns in our forests, as already foreshadowed by Senator Brownhill.

The conservation movement will have to resort once again to this course of action, putting themselves in front of bulldozers and putting themselves at great risk. Why should they have to do this? They simply should not have to do it. The areas which they are trying to save—

TALK.START.PARA: —I used to drive a bulldozer and I would not have stopped if you were in the way.

—I noted that comment by Senator Panizza. Many of these areas that they are attempting to save are on the National Estate. All Australians should be proud of these areas and we should baulk at the idea of simply flattening them. They are part of our national heritage just as the Sydney Opera House, old Parliament House or many of the significant buildings in our capital cities are.

PARA.TAB: Today the Wilderness Society put out a press release stating that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has applied to Michael Lee for approval to proceed with the logging of 51 coupes in forests listed on the register of the National Estate. Many of these coupes lie within the western Tasmanian wilderness area, the Great Western Tiers and the Norfolk Range, commonly referred to as the Tarkine wilderness. The 51 coupes occupy some 3,650 hectares—more than 36 square kilometres.

Logging is going on right now in the east Picton River region—a magnificent area of forest with the tallest flowering plants in the world, eucalyptus regnans. This area is on the National Estate. It was also identified by the IUCN as having world heritage value, but was not included by the federal government in the Tasmanian wilderness nomination because the area was sought after by the forest industry.

I heard one of the honourable senators interject when Senator Coulter was speaking that clear-felling does not happen anymore. I suggest that Senator Watson has a look at what is actually happening; nothing could be further from the truth. The truth is that the forestry industry has been running a very successful PR campaign trying to convince everybody that it is no longer going on. I suggest that honourable senators have a look at what really is happening.

The logging of old-growth forests is not sustainable because it irreversibly destroys our most ancient forests and, indeed, entire ecosystems. Many opposition senators like to quote certain sections of the Resource Assessment Commission report on the forest industry. I would like to bring to their attention the inquiry's main finding on the logging of old-growth forests—that is, that the logging of old-growth forests violates the precautionary principle and destroys an irreplaceable resource. The inquiry's preferred option was that logging in old-growth forests cease immediately.

The New South Wales Forestry Commission carries out clear-felling in the south-east forests. One of the most blatant examples of the state government's failure to commit itself to the national forests policy is the controversial decision to commence logging in compartment 1402 in the Nalbaugh State Forest. This area is listed on the National Estate and is part of the Coolangubra wilderness area. Compartment 1402 is home to five endangered animal species. There are other areas of the state under threat from logging, including Barrington, Chaleundi, the Kempsey-Wauchope forests and the old-growth forests of the Bulga Plateau.

In Victoria, the Brown Mountain on the Errinundra Plateau is up for logging. So too are the old-growth areas of Ellery Block and Yalmy Creek—two of the last pristine water catchments in the east Gippsland region. These areas are the home to the long-footed potoroo and animals supposedly protected by this government's Endangered Species Protection Act.

In Queensland, logging continues to take place in the state forest on the Clarke Range situated on either side of the Eungella National Park, west of Mackay, as well as the Conway State Forest, adjoining Conway National Park east of Proserpine. Both these areas have been identified as being of high conservation value and comprise old-growth forest types.

In Western Australia, the Court government has decided to triple the quantities of jarrah, karri and marri to be extracted from the south-west forests. This decision will have a catastrophic effect on the remaining old-growth forests and will greatly exacerbate problems associated with dieback in those forests.

The destruction of old-growth forests has to stop. The national forest policy requires that states avoid logging in these areas. The Democrats will continue to push the federal government to ensure that it carries out its leadership responsibilities and forces the states to implement the policy they agreed to last December.

Once again, the Democrats support value adding, but we refuse to support legislation which condones the destruction of our natural heritage. It is a crime against nature and against future generations of Australians. We call on the Minister for Resources to ensure that he applies stringent conditions to this year's export licences in conformity with Commonwealth policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good rhetoric, Senator Lees, but what has it got to do with these bills?
—As Senator Murphy has been listening, he would have heard very clearly that we will not pass these bills when effectively they condone further logging with value adding on our old-growth forests.

PARA.TAB: I will just add one more point and look at one other issue, and that is the management of our water catchment regions in the forest areas. A CSIRO press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: A group of international scientists will meet this week to reach consensus on urgent action needed to sustain the amount and quality of water supplied from forests.

Australia is suffering diminishing water resources. The quality of water coming from our forests is also a major concern. The international conference this week in Canberra will seek consensus of opinion on what action needs to be taken to advise government policy makers . . .
If honourable senators want a practical example of what is happening in east Gippsland as far as water catchment is concerned, take a look at the upper reaches of the Betka River.

PARA.TAB: That was logged despite enormous pressure from the local community and that is now threatening the water supply to Mallacoota. With a permanent population of 1,000, some people may simple dismiss that as irrelevant, but it is a very important area and no amount of discussion with the forestry industry was able to save that area, and that will lead to the degradation of the water supply in an area that is often at crisis point when the population builds up by 3,000 or 4,000 over Christmas.

I suggest that those honourable senators who criticise the Democrats' stand on these bills visit some of these forest areas that I have talked about tonight and see for themselves the destruction that is occurring and the destruction that this generation—in particular, those of us in parliament in the early 1990s—will be responsible for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the Senate desires that senators not speak for long, but I think it would be remiss of me, coming from Tasmania, not to say a few words about this most important piece of legislation. We have had a number of most interesting contributions at the second reading stage. Two Tasmanian senators who are in the chamber at the moment have spoken on the measure. Of course, I certainly do not hold myself out to have the breadth and depth of knowledge about this industry that Senators Gibson and Murphy do.

PARA.TAB: I take the opportunity to raise with the Senate a couple of questions arising from the last speaker's contribution. Senator Lees appeared to indicate that the Australian Democrats would not support this legislation until there was some clear manifestation that the authorities—the industry and the governments—intended to ensure that certain things occurred. The measures before us are simply to provide the finance for the corporation, which has already been established. It is not immediately clear to me how voting against this piece of legislation will achieve the results which Senator Lees and Senator Coulter have suggested should be achieved prior to this measure being passed by this parliament.

Under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act, regulations have already been made to establish the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. So the organisation has been established and a charter and function have been given to that organisation. What it lacks, of course, is money. These measures are to levy that money so that that organisation can pursue the very important task of research. It seems to me that, as I think has been said before in this debate, that research will do much to ensure that there are alternative measures to those which are condemned—broadly, I think, by everybody in the Senate and by many people outside the Senate—and which frequently have been condoned in previous years.

In respect of old-growth forests, I think there is a great deal to be done in determining a better system of operation for plantation forests—for example, better species and more effective collaboration between the processing industries and the production industry so that there is more focus on the plantation industries. Of course, new ideas take time. The corporation is required to come up with five-year plans, including objectives, strategies and policies, and to prepare annual operating plans for each financial year. We in the parliament will have access to those. They will be brought to the parliament and there will be plenty of opportunities to debate them. So the corporation's activities will be the subject of constant debate and consideration by the parliament.

As has been said, rarely has an industry had more investigations and more interest from the parliament than this industry. A spin-off of the research-driven activities of the corporation could be that we will be able to provide the information and the results of our research to other countries. In a global context, that is important, from the conservationists' point of view. If, through moneys which are proposed in this bill, through the corporation and through the activities of those organisations to which the moneys are disbursed by the corporation, we can develop species and techniques that will work in this country and can work in some of the other countries, then we may be able to save some of the old-growth forests in other countries, which we are all concerned about.

I do not want to labour this issue, but I want to make a point. As the Senate knows, I am very interested in the budget for the official development assistance programs that Australia funds through AIDAB. One of the things that I believe we are significantly lacking in this area is the provision of expertise to other countries in respect of the timber industry. I think we have the expertise in this country. This will give a boost to that expertise. I think that it will be a good thing not only for Australia but also for a number of other countries—and, incidentally, for the conservation movement throughout the world.
I intend to support this bill. I note for the record what was said in the second reading speech to these bills:

SPEECH.PARA: Already the Commonwealth provides significant support to forest industry research and development in several ways: through direct funding to CSIRO Divisions of Forestry, Forest Products, and Wildlife and Ecology; to the Cooperative Research Centres for Temperate Hardwood Forestry and Hardwood Fibre and Paper Science; and through such programs as the national pulp mill research program and the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation's agroforestry program. Research into forestry and forest products is also supported by the state governments and the forest industry.

I would not like to see the levy that we will collect as a result of the passage of this bill substituted for the money that is currently flowing to research. I would hope that it would be in addition to the moneys that are already flowing to research in that industry.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I will touch on the last point that Senator Harradine made. Forestry always seems to draw the sap. It flows pretty freely in these debates. It also seems to draw the Tasmanian contribution. I notice that in this debate there are four speakers from Tasmania, including Senator Harradine, Senator Gibson and Senator Murphy. Later in my speech I will make a brief reference to their contributions.
—If you had been here 10 years ago, you would have heard every Tasmanian talking about the Launceston airport.

—I know all about the Launceston airport. I do not want to digress, but when Launceston airport was constructed, in the early 1960s, the federal Minister for Civil Aviation at the time, who I think was a Liberal, made sure that Launceston had the third largest airport terminal in Australia—a tribute to the expertise of Tasmanian lobbying power. May it continue.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the last issue raised by Senator Harradine—an inveterate lobbyist for the Tasmanian position, as evidenced by the last budget—the funding that has been raised through this levy will be additional. There are no plans or no intention on the part of the government to cut back the research effort in other areas. Whilst this is an important piece of legislation and an important segment of forestry research in Australia, the other contributions being made by such organisations as CSIRO will continue and are particularly important. I thank Senator Harradine for what was a well-balanced and measured assessment of this legislation.

Senator Coulter, Senator Chamarette, Senator Margetts and Senator Lees—her final fling was a little polemic but, nevertheless, it was a typical Australian Democrat approach; I will not go beyond that in terms of abuse—are entitled to their view but, frankly, their contributions were not particularly relevant to the bills we are debating. We had some significant contributions. I accept that the Greens and the Democrats have a perspective of forestry that is different from that of some of us. I accept that they have, in some cases, some legitimate criticisms of forestry. The Greens and the Democrats have advanced these criticisms in the past.

We are dealing with a piece of legislation that, under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989—forestry is, in a significant sense, a primary industry—provides for a levy to be collected by a research and development corporation. This will be set up as a body corporate with day-to-day autonomy—I stress that, because it is important in the context of what it will conduct research into—and flexibility to operate in a similar manner to that of many other commercial organisations, including the numerous commercial primary industry organisations that are not dictated to by government or, indeed, the particular sector of the industry they represent.

The purpose of the corporation will be to provide a national strategic leadership to industry research and development and to act as a catalyst to stimulate research and development within the forest industries. Its charter will include—I am sorry that Senator Lees is not here to hear my contribution—the ecological and environmental impact of disturbance resulting from wood production, silviculture and management of native forests and plantations. So the charter will include the sorts of issues that speakers such as Senator Coulter and Senator Chamarette, who I think quite legitimately are concerned with environmental issues, spoke about. I, frankly, do not believe that the sort of attack they mounted on the legislation tonight is justified.

I want to emphasise a stronger economic theme. I suppose this is one of the issues that concerns me greatly in the forestry debate. Whilst I do not put aside the legitimate environmental considerations, one of the tragic economic facts of life for this country today is that we are a significant net importer of forest products. We imported about $2 1/2 billion of forestry products in the last calendar year and we exported about $780 million or $0.8 billion. So we have a trade deficit of about $1.6 billion in forestry products.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because you would not build the pulp mills.

—I agree to some extent with the interjection. One dollar in every 10 of this country's deficit is in forest products. The great tragedy for this country is that if we could convert and downstream much of what we export in the form of woodchips or whatever, we would in fact be a net exporter of value added forestry products.

PARA.TAB: I notice that there were a couple of interjections about the mill in Tasmania and about resource security. I do not want to be too unkind to the opposition—it is supporting us on this legislation—but where was it last year on resource security? Unfortunately—this must be to its embarrassment—I seem to recall the Democrats and the one Green senator at that stage voting with the opposition on resource security. Senator Coulter is blushing and interjecting with pride at that magnificent combination of strategic alliances, much to Senator Gibson's disgust. I do not want to be too unkind and remind those opposite of that unfortunate alliance that occurred last year.

I do not want to spend any more time on this legislation. I appreciate the contributions of the opposition members. I appreciate their support. I do not believe that the general theme advanced by the Democrat and Green senators is particularly relevant to the legislation.

I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I particularly thank my Tasmanian colleagues. I have to say that on both sides they bring a reasonable degree of commonsense to this debate. If one lives in Tasmania, if one has lived through these debates for the last 15 years, there is not much about forestry one does not know. Senator Gibson, Senator Harradine and my colleague Senator Murphy, who has been much more closely involved with this industry than most others, realise the importance of this industry to Australia; the importance of having an effective research and development program, not just to serve the purposes of those people involved in forest industries but also to ensure that we have a forest industry that is environmentally sustainable, that is taking into account the legitimate environmental concerns.

I do not often finish on a point that Senator Harradine raises, but I think the point is very important. Senator Harradine spoke about using the expertise we have developed in forestry as an export industry. I have visited Indonesia and Malaysia and some of the practices in those countries are tragic. These practices, which are resulting in degradation, erosion and environmental problems, are appalling. I believe that in many cases the Australian forest industry can make an effective contribution to improving the forest industries in the areas of South-East Asia in particular.

I commend the legislation to the committee. I think it is a very sensible package that provides for a balanced research effort, not just into the economic considerations of forestry but also into the very critical environmental factors.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any amendments but I have some questions I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary. The first question I would like to ask him is in relation to forestry. Does he believe that there should be full cost recovery; in other words, that the absolutely enormous subsidies which I mentioned in my speech that have gone into forestry since the 1920s—something over $4 billion or $5 billion over that time—should disappear and that the full costs of taking trees out of the forest should be recovered?

PARA.TAB: I think the government is talking market forces; certainly the opposition is talking market forces. Specifically, does he believe that there should be complete internalisation of all the externalities in relation to logging forests, recognising that there are costs in the loss of forests which go beyond simply the value of the wood—we have alluded to many of those tonight—and that those costs also need to be incorporated into the costs which are charged against the forestry industry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coulter for his question. Full cost recovery is a desirable long-term objective. Senator Coulter has probably read the national forest policy statement. It is a desirable long-term objective that we maximise cost recovery in the forest industry, recognising that, whatever our particular attitude is to the responsibility of state and federal governments, a very significant responsibility lies in the hands of the states in this regard.

PARA.TAB: Page 20 of the national forest policy statement on the issue of wood pricing and allocation states:

SPEECH.PARA: Prices will be market based, at least cover the full cost of efficient management (including regeneration) attributable to wood production, include a fair return on capital, and provide an adequate return to the community from the use of a public resource.

A sensible approach to that is that obviously it will not occur tomorrow. The forest industry involves a very complex set of interrelationships in both the harvesting of forest products and their processing in a variety of forms. It will take some years to achieve, but that is our overall policy objective.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees referred to a conference on water policy in Australia, which I had the pleasure of opening on Monday. Every major policy initiative of this government in the environmental, primary industry and resources areas is focused on taking into account the real costs of recovery and production in these resource sectors. It is a complex issue and not one that we can resolve easily tomorrow. It has to take into account a reasonable time frame and the relative balance in political responsibilities between state and central governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) for that answer because it provided two bits of information. Firstly, it answered Senator Harradine's query about the relevance of the Democrats' objection to this legislation. I notice that the reply went immediately to the national forest policy and I can tell Senator Harradine that that is what we are concerned about—that the government is implementing part of the national forest policy but not other parts which we believe to be even more important.

PARA.TAB: The other important thing which the parliamentary secretary has just said is that the government will continue to subsidise forestry in Australia. I want to make it absolutely clear—and get it on the record so that everybody understands it—that this federal government will be putting money into value adding to forestry products but at the same time will continue to subsidise the destruction of our old-growth forests for an indefinite period. That is what the parliamentary secretary has said and it is now clearly on the record.

The second point I would like Senator Sherry to deal with is a concern that has been expressed to me, particularly in Western Australia and Tasmania. Many craft workers in those states have found themselves locked out of mixed old-growth forests where they wish to go and take what are known as the minority species, many of which often make extremely high quality, very expensive furniture and pieces of timber. They have been locked out of those areas when those areas have been clear-felled on the grounds that it is simply easier for those who are clear-felling and chipping an area to do that and not worry about craftspeople coming in and selectively taking out those trees which have a very high value.

One has seen in factories in the south-west of Western Australia and in Tasmania—indeed, in Hobart—pieces of furniture priced at thousands of dollars made from these minority species and the people making this furniture complaining that they have great difficulty getting access to the wood. If this bill is about value adding, surely there should be some assurance from this government—because this government is passing the legislation—that that will not continue and that those people who are making these high quality pieces of furniture and other timber products out of these minority species will continue to have access to them in these areas that will continue to be harvested. I would also like some assurance of that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Coulter has gone a good way beyond the subject matter of this legislation. I have been to the furniture design centre in Hobart and, together with a number of Tasmanian representatives and senators, I have been actively involved in lobbying to ensure that that design centre continues to receive funding to actively involve itself—it is not the only organisation in Tasmania, I might add—in important value adding issues, such as furniture design.

PARA.TAB: There is a limited resource because, both within the national forest policy statement—and I know Tasmania is not yet a party to it as yet—and the various environmental guidelines that apply to forestry in Tasmania, there is a limit on the resource. Frankly, that is not unexpected. I cannot give a guarantee here tonight that the furniture centre will have X amount of timber tomorrow. I believe generally—

TALK.START.PARA: —That isn't what I mean.
—I think it is what Senator Coulter was asking. He was asking for guarantees from the federal government about—
—About craftspeople getting access.

—Broadly speaking, that is occurring in Tasmania. Where there are some shortages of timber, it is localised for both climatic and environmental considerations that are particularly important in the Tasmanian context.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter asked whether the Commonwealth continues to subsidise forests in Australia. We do not subsidise forestry in Australia. The Commonwealth government is not involved in that respect. I refer Senator Coulter to my earlier answer on cost recovery and the responsibility of the states within the context of the national forest policy statement.
I do not wish to be as harsh as Senator McGauran was in criticising Senator Coulter in his attitudes on forestry and employment and unemployment—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made twice as many speeches per unit of time.

—I noted Senator Coulter's analysis of the speeches this afternoon and I am not criticising him for that, but we should draw the committee's attention to the important fact that forestry is one of the major regional industries in Australia. There is a $10 billion turnover in forestry, largely in rural and regional Australia. It is a very important industry. Whilst I accept that the sort of issues Senator Coulter is raising have a legitimate connection to this legislation, they are not the central and core issues. The central and core issue is a research and development structure providing for funding to overcome some of the very issues he complains about.

—It is interesting that Senator Sherry is evidently not aware that, although these minority species are in limited supply, what I know has happened in Western Australia and Tasmania—and it may well have happened in other states—is that individual craftspeople have been denied access to those trees in forest areas which have been clear-felled. They have not been allowed to go in and specifically take out those trees, even knowing that all those trees will be felled and sent off to the chippers. This legislation is partly about a levy to get value adding into forestry industries—something we said that we agree with. But Senator Sherry is evidently not aware that that has happened.

PARA.TAB: The third issue I raise with Senator Sherry is that of the efficient use of forest timber. It is estimated that roughly 30 per cent of the available timber in clear-felled areas is left on the forest floor instead of going off to the chippers. Daishowa has mobile chippers which it could send into the forest; they could chip branches and take everything down to the mill. That is not done quite simply because the timber carters for Daishowa are contractors who are paid for the weight of timber that they transport. It is more convenient for them to simply take the logs and leave all the large branches and everything else as trash on the forest floor, very often to be burnt.

In many other countries, such as Sweden, the whole tree is used. We could substantially reduce the area of forest which we clear if we used the whole tree, particularly in those cases in which we are going to chip. I have been around long enough to know that when the woodchip industry got under way it undertook to government that it was going to use only the waste material; it was not going to use the primary logs at all. What, if anything, does this government intend to do to increase the efficiency with which the timber that is felled in the forest is used? Is it going to try to see that 100 per cent of the tree is used, not only 70 per cent as happens at present?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With due respect to Senator Coulter, the issue he is raising, whilst being important, is not a central issue to this legislation. To respond to his question, the basic tenet of the principles that are enunciated in the national forest policy statement is that there will be an allocation system for timber that will be flexible and will involve competitive bidding.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter made a broad brush, emotive statement that timber is being sent off to the chippers which should be used for the sorts of value adding that he highlights. He mentioned the craftspeople; I have seen many of the good works they do. I concede that occasionally a log might get through which should not go to the chipper. But, by and large, the practices of the forestry commissions—not just in Tasmania, but also the other forestry departments—ensure that those poor quality logs and those poor quality sectors of the log which are left over after use for sawlogging are consigned to a lower value adding area of the industry. Overwhelmingly, that is the practice in the industry.

Senator Coulter referred earlier to a system based on cost recovery and a rational use of pricing policies. That is a central element of the forest policy statement. That will enable the entry of new processors and will allow the small operators to which he refers to compete in those niche markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —My final question relates to the last part of the closing speech at the second reading stage in which reference was made to the amount of forest product which Australia imports each year. I think it was mentioned that the trade imbalance was $1.6 billion. I think Senator Sherry also mentioned that if we turned some of the chips which we now export—very low value adding chips—into paper and value added product, we could turn that situation around.

PARA.TAB: My understanding was that when Harris Daishowa—as it was when it first began—was given its first licences, it undertook to build a pulp mill in Australia. That has not happened. It is still exporting chips. These licences are coming up for renewal. What is the government going to do in relation to that undertaking? As I understand it, that was a clear undertaking to value add to those chips. It has not occurred over many years. What is the government going to do? Is it going to hold Daishowa to that promise?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —To be perfectly blunt, I think Senator Coulter is trying to have it both ways. The fundamental question is: will we be allowed to build a pulp mill, to value add with those chips we export? Senator Coulter wants to have it both ways.

PARA.TAB: I will get as angry as I ever have in this Senate. I have been through this debate in the Tasmanian context. Really, I think Senator Coulter has a gall to request that this government value add by processing the chips we export and impose that as a licence condition on the current evaluation of exporting of chips. I would be very happy to go to my minister and say that we will do that, provided that Senator Coulter will give me an undertaking—which I know he will not give—and provided that the Greens will give me an undertaking that they will support the number of pulp and paper mills that would eventuate as a consequence of that policy. There would probably be two or three of them. I would love to see an environmentally responsible pulp and paper industry develop in Australia based on that chip export industry that we have at the present time.

One of the great tragedies of this forest industry debate in Australia is that we seem to be locked into particular positions where there cannot be a reasonable outcome on this issue. As I said earlier in my speech, we are a net importer of forest products in Australia when we should be a net exporter. One dollar in every $10 of our total debt is incurred as a consequence of the particular difficulty we are locked into. That is a shame and it is a regrettable reflection of the relative immaturity with which we approach the debate on forest issues.

I will not lay all the blame at the feet of the environmentalists. The approach of some of the developments that are being proposed in the handling of some of the environmental issues—not purely the public relations issue—has been a little naive. It is a sad reflection on the country and it is a cost that we are all paying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just smooth Senator Sherry down; I would not like to see him go away angry. He will not have an argument with me about building an appropriate pulp mill or going on and making paper. Where he will have an argument is in relation to the methods which are used.

PARA.TAB: In my own state of South Australia, the pulp mill used processes of digesting the lignocellulose and bleaching, which were very destructive, and we have enormous problems with Lake Bonney. Over many years, the company concerned said that there were no other methods of bleaching or digestion which could be used. They are now increasingly shifting to those newer and environmentally cleaner methods of carrying out that work.

I have been strongly promoting the use of alternative fibres in paper making for many years: low THC hemp in the southern parts, possibly flax, and kenaf in the northern parts of Australia. We should be making more of our own paper. These alternative fibres have the advantage of having much less lignin, requiring much less digestion and, therefore, being much less environmentally damaging. This also, incidentally, is providing the Queensland canegrowers with a very viable alternative crop.

Australia has spent an enormous amount of money—10 years of research work through CSIRO—on doing the work on kenaf. It is now being used in the States. The Dutch have taken up the hemp work and they are producing paper in Holland. We should be doing these things. I strongly supported those measures. So Senator Sherry certainly will not find any argument with me over increasing our production of paper and products of that sort, provided the processes are environmentally sensible and sane. I do not think that those processes have been carried out in that way in the past. That is my only argument there.

The sorts of innovative measures he wants to see will be sponsored by, in part, the legislation, the levy and the research effort that will result from this legislation. He is spot-on and that is why he should be supporting this legislation.
